log\u2009<em>M</em>\u00a0\u2261\u00a0log(<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">\u2060|$M_{\\rm H_2}$|</span>\u00a0[M<sub>\u2299</sub>]).</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-tblf5\"></span><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/[XSLTSectionID][QueryString]\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div> \n    </div>\n\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n    <div class=\"widget widget-SiteWideModals widget-instance-SiteWideModals\">\n        <div id=\"revealModal\" (function () {\r\n            var hfSiteUrl = document.getElementById('hfSiteURL');\r\n            var siteUrl = hfSiteUrl.value;\r\n            var subdomainIndex = siteUrl.indexOf('/');\r\n\r\n $(this).find('.icon-general-add, .icon-minus').toggleClass('icon-minus icon-general-add');\r\n            $(this).siblings('.ati-toggle-content').toggleClass('hide');\r\n        });\r\n\r\n        // In Chrome, an anchor tag with target=\"_blank\" and a \"mailto:\" href opens a new tab/window as well as the email client\r\n        // I suspect this behavior will be corrected in the future\r\n        // Remove the target=\"_blank\"\r\n        $('ul.wi-affiliationList').find('a[href^=\"mailto:\"]').each(function () {\r\n            $(this).removeAttr('target');\r\n        });\r\n microsite-search-term\" type=\"text\" maxlength=\"255\" id=\"MicrositeSearchTerm\" title=\"search input\">\r\n\r\n                            <a href=\"javascript:;\" id=\"MicrositeSearchIcon\"     <div class=\"navbar-search-advanced\"><a href=\"/mnras/advanced-search\" class=\"advanced-search js-advanced-search\">Advanced Search</a></div>\r\n            </div>            <div class=\"navbar-search-collapsed\"><a href=\"javascript:;\" class=\"icon-menu_search js_expand-navsearch\"><span class=\"screenreader-text\">Search Menu</span></a></div>\r\n    </div>\r\n</div>\r\n\r\n<input id=\"hfEnableOupOnlineProductsFeatures\" name=\"hfEnableOupOnlineProductsFeatures\" type=\"hidden\" value=\"False\" />\r\n\r\n<input id=\"routename\" name=\"RouteName\" type=\"hidden\" value=\"mnras\" /> \n    </div>\n\r\n                    </div>\r\n                </div>\r\n            </div>\r\n            <div id=\"ContentTab\" class=\"content active\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget widget-ArticleFulltext widget-instance-OUP_Article_FullText_Widget\">\n        <div class=\"module-widget\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget-items\" data-widgetname=\"ArticleFulltext\">\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n                    <h2 scrollto-destination=133989578 id=\"133989578\" class=\"abstract-title\" >ABSTRACT</h2>\r\n<section class=\"abstract\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Follow-up observations of (sub-)mm-selected gravitationally lensed systems have allowed a more detailed study of the dust-enshrouded phase of star formation up to very early cosmic times. Here, the case of the gravitationally lensed merger in HATLAS\u00a0J142935.3\u2013002836 (also known as H1429\u22120028; <em>z</em><sub>lens</sub>\u00a0=\u00a00.218, <em>z</em><sub>bkg</sub>\u00a0=\u00a01.027) is revisited following recent developments in the literature and new Atacama Pathfinder EXperiment (APEX) observations targeting two carbon monoxide (CO) rotational transitions J<sub>up</sub>\u00a0=\u00a03 and 6. We show that the line profiles comprise three distinct velocity components, where the fainter high velocity one is less magnified and more compact. The modelling of the observed spectral line energy distribution of CO J<sub>up</sub>\u00a0=\u00a02\u20136 and [C\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">i</span>]\u00a0<sup>3</sup><em>P</em><sub>1</sub>\u2212<sup>3</sup><em>P</em><sub>0</sub> assumes a large velocity gradient scenario, where the analysis is based on four statistical approaches. Since the detected gas and dust emission comes exclusively from only one of the two merging components (the one oriented north\u2013south, NS), we are only able to determine upper limits for the companion. The molecular gas in the NS component in H1429\u22120028 is found to have a temperature of \u223c70\u00a0K, a volume density of log\u2009(<em>n</em>[cm<sup>\u22123</sup>])\u00a0\u223c\u00a03.7, to be expanding at \u223c10\u00a0km\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup>\u00a0pc<sup>\u22121</sup>, and amounts to <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${M_{\\rm H_2} = 4_{-2}^{+3} \\times 10^9\\,{\\rm M}_\\odot }$|\u2060</span>. The CO to H<sub>2</sub> conversion factor is estimated to be <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\alpha _{\\rm CO} = 0.4_{-0.2}^{+0.3}\\,$|</span>\u00a0M<sub>\u2299</sub>/(K\u00a0km\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup>\u00a0pc<sup>2</sup>). The NS galaxy is expected to have a factor of \u227310\u00d7 more gas than its companion (<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">\u2060|${M_{\\rm H_2}}\\lesssim 3\\times 10^8$|</span>\u00a0M<sub>\u2299</sub>). Nevertheless, the total amount of molecular gas in the system comprises only up to 15\u00a0per\u00a0cent (1\u03c3 upper limit) of the total (dynamical) mass.</p></section>                        <div class=\"article-metadata-panel clearfix\"></div>\r\n<div class=\"kwd-group\"><a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;gravitational lensing: strong&quot;\">gravitational lensing: strong</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;ISM: abundances&quot;\">ISM: abundances</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;galaxies: interactions&quot;\">galaxies: interactions</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;submillimetre: galaxies&quot;\">submillimetre: galaxies</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;submillimetre: ISM&quot;\">submillimetre: ISM</a></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=133989580 id=\"133989580\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec1>1 INTRODUCTION</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Understanding the life cycle of galaxies necessitates an observational multiwavelength approach, not only due to the many evolution tracks a galaxy may follow (e.g. finishing as an early-type galaxy, or as an \u2018untouched\u2019 disc galaxy as NGC\u00a01277; Trujillo et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib81\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib81\" data-open=\"bib81\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>), but also the many physical mechanisms at play (e.g. star formation and its quenching, heavy elements production), and the advantages and disadvantages specific to different methods of analysis.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Specifically, the brightest of the dusty star-forming galaxies (DSFGs; see Casey, Narayanan\u00a0&amp;\u00a0Cooray <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib12\" data-open=\"bib12\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>, for a review), also referred to as submillimetre galaxies (SMGs; Smail, Ivison\u00a0&amp;\u00a0Blain <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib72\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib72\" data-open=\"bib72\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1997</a>; Hughes et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib33\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib33\" data-open=\"bib33\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1998</a>), provide a strong case for the early active evolution stages of the most massive galaxies seen in the local Universe (e.g. Simpson et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib71\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib71\" data-open=\"bib71\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>; Toft et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib79\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib79\" data-open=\"bib79\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>). Despite not being representative of the whole galaxy population, SMGs may enable us to unveil the dusty origins of the local Universe\u2019s massive monsters, as seen in a Universe with less than 25\u00a0per\u00a0cent its current age (<em>z</em>\u00a0\u2273\u00a02). They are highly star forming and already massive galaxies, quickly exhausting their large gas reservoirs, and with a source density comparable to massive galaxies in the local Universe (Casey et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib12\" data-open=\"bib12\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>). Whether or not the SMG phase is responsible for the build-up of the bulk of the stellar populations in massive galaxies today is still a matter of active discussion, but what is clear is that this short-lived phase can indeed induce a significant galaxy growth in relatively small cosmological time intervals (<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">\u2060|${\\sim }100\\,$|</span>\u00a0Myr).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">A useful characteristic of DSFGs is that, among the brightest of their kind, there are easily selected strongly lensed systems (Negrello et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib54\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib54\" data-open=\"bib54\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; Vieira et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib83\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib83\" data-open=\"bib83\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; Wardlow et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib87\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib87\" data-open=\"bib87\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>) that can be exploited to probe this intriguing galaxy population down to fainter fluxes and higher resolution. These chance alignments are nevertheless rare (less than one per deg<sup>2</sup>; Negrello et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib54\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib54\" data-open=\"bib54\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>) and require wide field surveys. These have been possible in recent years with facilities such as the <em>Herschel Space Observatory</em> (<em>Herschel</em>), South Pole Telescope (SPT), or <em>Planck</em>, which enabled <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\gt 100\\,$|</span>\u00a0deg<sup>2</sup> surveys at far-infrared (FIR) to millimetre (mm) wavelengths. The <em>Herschel</em> Astrophysical Terahertz Large Area Survey (HATLAS; Eales et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib22\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib22\" data-open=\"bib22\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>) has covered different patches of the 100\u2013500\u00a0<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mu {\\rm m}$|</span> sky amounting to 570\u00a0deg<sup>2</sup>. The <em>Herschel</em> Stripe\u00a082 Survey (HerS; Viero et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib85\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib85\" data-open=\"bib85\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>) and the HerMES Large Mode Survey (HeLMS; Oliver et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib58\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib58\" data-open=\"bib58\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>) covered, respectively, 280 and 95\u00a0deg<sup>2</sup> of the sky at 250\u2013500\u00a0<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mu {\\rm m}$|\u2060</span>. The SPT covered 2500\u00a0deg<sup>2</sup> of the southern sky at 1\u20133\u00a0mm (Williamson et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib88\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib88\" data-open=\"bib88\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>). Finally, the <em>Planck</em> mission covered the whole sky at 0.35\u201310\u00a0mm (Planck Collaboration I <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib64\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib64\" data-open=\"bib64\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">There are now numerous cases of gravitationally lensed galaxies for exploration of the finer details of galaxy evolution at earlier times. This is done by intensive follow-up campaigns of these systems, for instance, via high-resolution multiwavelength imaging enabling rest-frame optical to FIR reconstruction of the background source plane (e.g. Negrello et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib54\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib54\" data-open=\"bib54\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; Calanog et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib8\" data-open=\"bib8\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>; Messias et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib49\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib49\" data-open=\"bib49\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>; Timmons et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib78\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib78\" data-open=\"bib78\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>), or optical to mm spectroscopy to constrain the distances to lens and lensed galaxies (e.g. Scott et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib68\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib68\" data-open=\"bib68\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>; Lupu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib46\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib46\" data-open=\"bib46\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Vieira et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib84\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib84\" data-open=\"bib84\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>; Strandet et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib75\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib75\" data-open=\"bib75\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>; Negrello et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib55\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib55\" data-open=\"bib55\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>) and the gas conditions and content of the star-bursting background systems (e.g. Riechers et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib65\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib65\" data-open=\"bib65\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>; Harris et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib31\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib31\" data-open=\"bib31\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Timmons et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib77\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib77\" data-open=\"bib77\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>; Bothwell et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib7\" data-open=\"bib7\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>; Oteo et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib59\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib59\" data-open=\"bib59\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017a</a>; Strandet et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib76\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib76\" data-open=\"bib76\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>; Yang et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib90\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib90\" data-open=\"bib90\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>; Ca\u00f1ameras et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib9\" data-open=\"bib9\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>; Motta et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib51\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib51\" data-open=\"bib51\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>).</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=133989585 id=\"133989585\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec1-1>1.1 The HATLAS\u00a0J142935.3\u2013002836 case</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">This paper reports the latest advances in comprehending the gravitationally lensed system in HATLAS\u00a0J142935.3\u2013002836 (also known as H1429\u22120028; Messias et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib49\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib49\" data-open=\"bib49\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>, hereafter M14). M14 reported the initial findings on H1429\u22120028 that appeared as the brightest of an early set of candidates for gravitationally lensed galaxies in HATLAS (an observed FIR flux at <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$160\\, \\mu {\\rm m}$|</span> of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$S_{160\\, \\mu {\\rm m}}\\sim 1.2$|</span>\u00a0Jy). It was found that H1429\u22120028 comprises an edge-on disc galaxy at <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.218 acting as lens, surrounded by an almost complete Einstein ring with a 3\u20134\u00a0knot morphology. Subarcsec imaging at near-IR to radio wavelengths enabled reconstruction of the background source to reveal a merging system magnified by an overall factor of \u223c10 and comprising two distinct galaxies at <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a01.027 (M14). One galaxy has an east\u2013west orientation dominating the rest-frame optical spectral range (henceforth known as the EW galaxy/component). The other, appearing north\u2013south oriented and with a compact intrinsic half-light radius <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$r_{1/2} = 0.9\\pm 0.3$|</span>\u00a0kpc, dominates the gaseous and dusty content of the system, being the main contributor to the long-wavelength spectral regime flux (henceforth known as the NS galaxy/component). In Dye et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib21\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib21\" data-open=\"bib21\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>), the magnification factor of the dust component in NS was revised to be \u223c23, further highlighting the need for proper magnification lensing analysis incorporating complex morphologies. Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a> shows a toy model to help understand the background system. Specifically the inset shows the velocity map of the NS galaxy, where it is clear that its southern region is more blueshifted than the northern one where a peak in velocity dispersion is seen (M14). A more detailed discussion can be found in M14 (specifically, figs\u00a01 and 8 therein).</p>                        <a id=\"133989587\" scrollto-destination=\"133989587\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig1\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure\u00a01.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/486/2/10.1093_mnras_stz945/1/m_stz945fig1.jpeg?Expires=1611465158&amp;Signature=rvqMt6mrfbE8HagLsJuraA9zBaf7b7dh2O1h9~897lm0q3ER7dDlg9itjm0sLXQfAdTciINCgHhq6A3EyG2hLrFAZMyCAStl18-rKHqRoK3wBxqykubkWt5AlktrKPOwIINNYmhQlVy7y7r8EK~hP1gFVS4IeZ0ggEf5-cZ7GWcOKdlOgWZqi0-M~v7tIR0MEu8OPYIcqNtFwR~~Ik8BobQOtFYOeHQo7oSejyGqNgEq7FZ2HGy59UIQOLVi4RdWJ9UQjIWqzXyVHTS7oOTaAybxAFjdkUsOzlQnWyAgyDBCNyh~iz~rZZXR~KTOjCmDODwU6xh7Rpa3aNdGex8~6g__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"This toy model shows a simplified view of the background merger in H1429\u22120028. The east\u2013west oriented galaxy (EW) dominates the rest-frame optical spectral range, while the north\u2013south oriented one (NS) dominates the long-wavelength spectral regime. The caustic is overlaid as a dashed blue line. The currently inferred impact direction is indicated with the black arrows (see Section\u00a04.1). The inset shows the velocity map (moment-1) of the NS galaxy (M14), where the colour bar extends from \u2212150 to 150\u00a0km\u00a0s\u22121.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz945fig1.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/133989587/stz945fig1.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz945fig1.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"133989587\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/486/2/10.1093_mnras_stz945/1/stz945fig1.jpeg?Expires=1611465158&Signature=aHzWZLcUXWgjswBwrCQFTxhKCIkMufMkYPiWgDmDtCDMHofHgERfH-RDZh~WeO5ZZRMY7LvEoY2Dx07901E2O0AAYcX38-2Q8kMAxJ~OqymtFv-L77MVCAZZhGXyg4H3T1zKUxDm1yfuKhlmISSGPGUVwhzD03yOdDvMbIDxZWFAF71pZi6ucUpcbrQmSN9hKtSgGru7C5cQeuS~HoIw~s0ocaKGk3wQwy44J3qXzPtO5VLN86bARtNNutEl6-LSTSkXzt4GfSeBpp-Xdtdk8XkhkAV6Nf8mBvh9y8ccfbZq2WbKxy3HA19iZplFtRVxtvyI9rl0sAOeZdR6zMr0Hg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=133989587&ar=5475133&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz945fig1.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">This toy model shows a simplified view of the background merger in H1429\u22120028. The east\u2013west oriented galaxy (EW) dominates the rest-frame optical spectral range, while the north\u2013south oriented one (NS) dominates the long-wavelength spectral regime. The caustic is overlaid as a dashed blue line. The currently inferred impact direction is indicated with the black arrows (see Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec4-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">4.1</a>). The inset shows the velocity map (moment-1) of the NS galaxy (M14), where the colour bar extends from \u2212150 to 150\u00a0km\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup>.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig1\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure\u00a01.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/486/2/10.1093_mnras_stz945/1/m_stz945fig1.jpeg?Expires=1611465158&amp;Signature=rvqMt6mrfbE8HagLsJuraA9zBaf7b7dh2O1h9~897lm0q3ER7dDlg9itjm0sLXQfAdTciINCgHhq6A3EyG2hLrFAZMyCAStl18-rKHqRoK3wBxqykubkWt5AlktrKPOwIINNYmhQlVy7y7r8EK~hP1gFVS4IeZ0ggEf5-cZ7GWcOKdlOgWZqi0-M~v7tIR0MEu8OPYIcqNtFwR~~Ik8BobQOtFYOeHQo7oSejyGqNgEq7FZ2HGy59UIQOLVi4RdWJ9UQjIWqzXyVHTS7oOTaAybxAFjdkUsOzlQnWyAgyDBCNyh~iz~rZZXR~KTOjCmDODwU6xh7Rpa3aNdGex8~6g__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"This toy model shows a simplified view of the background merger in H1429\u22120028. The east\u2013west oriented galaxy (EW) dominates the rest-frame optical spectral range, while the north\u2013south oriented one (NS) dominates the long-wavelength spectral regime. The caustic is overlaid as a dashed blue line. The currently inferred impact direction is indicated with the black arrows (see Section\u00a04.1). The inset shows the velocity map (moment-1) of the NS galaxy (M14), where the colour bar extends from \u2212150 to 150\u00a0km\u00a0s\u22121.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz945fig1.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/133989587/stz945fig1.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz945fig1.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"133989587\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/486/2/10.1093_mnras_stz945/1/stz945fig1.jpeg?Expires=1611465158&Signature=aHzWZLcUXWgjswBwrCQFTxhKCIkMufMkYPiWgDmDtCDMHofHgERfH-RDZh~WeO5ZZRMY7LvEoY2Dx07901E2O0AAYcX38-2Q8kMAxJ~OqymtFv-L77MVCAZZhGXyg4H3T1zKUxDm1yfuKhlmISSGPGUVwhzD03yOdDvMbIDxZWFAF71pZi6ucUpcbrQmSN9hKtSgGru7C5cQeuS~HoIw~s0ocaKGk3wQwy44J3qXzPtO5VLN86bARtNNutEl6-LSTSkXzt4GfSeBpp-Xdtdk8XkhkAV6Nf8mBvh9y8ccfbZq2WbKxy3HA19iZplFtRVxtvyI9rl0sAOeZdR6zMr0Hg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=133989587&ar=5475133&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz945fig1.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">This toy model shows a simplified view of the background merger in H1429\u22120028. The east\u2013west oriented galaxy (EW) dominates the rest-frame optical spectral range, while the north\u2013south oriented one (NS) dominates the long-wavelength spectral regime. The caustic is overlaid as a dashed blue line. The currently inferred impact direction is indicated with the black arrows (see Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec4-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">4.1</a>). The inset shows the velocity map (moment-1) of the NS galaxy (M14), where the colour bar extends from \u2212150 to 150\u00a0km\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup>.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">In M14, the information available at the time only allowed for the determination of the expected range of molecular gas content. As a result, Atacama Pathfinder EXperiment (APEX) observations were conducted to observe extra carbon monoxide (CO) transitions, thus improving its spectral line energy distribution (SLED), together with the already observed [C\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">i</span>]\u2009<sup>3</sup><em>P</em><sub>1</sub>\u2212<sup>3</sup><em>P</em><sub>0</sub>, enables us to assess the gas conditions and content in H1429. Such observations are detailed in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2\"></span><a href=\"#sec2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">2</a>, whose results are used together with the lines reported in M14 to pursue a large velocity gradient (LVG) analysis of the CO\u00a0+\u00a0[C\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">i</span>] SLED in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3\"></span><a href=\"#sec3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3</a>. The implications of the results presented here are discussed in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4\"></span><a href=\"#sec4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">4</a>. Finally, Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5\"></span><a href=\"#sec5\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">5</a> presents the concluding remarks.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Throughout this paper, the following \u039b cold dark matter (\u039bCDM) cosmology is adopted: <em>H</em><sub>0</sub>\u00a0=\u00a070\u00a0km\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup>\u00a0Mpc<sup>\u22121</sup>, \u03a9<sub>M</sub>\u00a0=\u00a00.3, and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\Omega _\\Lambda = 0.7$|\u2060</span>. The cosmic microwave background (CMB) is assumed to expand adiabatically (<em>T<sub>z</sub></em>\u00a0=\u00a0T<sub>0</sub>\u00a0\u00d7\u00a0(1\u00a0+\u00a0<em>z</em>), with <em>T</em><sub>0</sub>\u00a0=\u00a0 2.726; Muller et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib52\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib52\" data-open=\"bib52\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>). When stated, the gas mass estimates are corrected by a factor of 1.36 to account for chemical elements heavier than hydrogen, assuming the latter comprises 73\u201374\u00a0per\u00a0cent of the total baryonic matter mass (Croswell <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib14\" data-open=\"bib14\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1996</a>; Carroll\u00a0&amp;\u00a0Ostlie <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib11\" data-open=\"bib11\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>).</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=133989590 id=\"133989590\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2>2 OBSERVATIONS</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Prior to this work, only CO\u2009J<sub>up</sub>\u00a0=\u00a0[2,4,5], [C\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">i</span>]\u2009<sup>3</sup><em>P</em><sub>1</sub>\u2212<sup>3</sup><em>P</em><sub>0</sub>, and CS\u2009(10\u20139) had been observed toward H1429\u22120028. The limited number of spectral features precluded a reliable analysis of the molecular gas content in the system. It was not clear if a two-component CO SLED existed and, given the redshifts of the lens (<em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.218) and sources (<em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a01.027), there was the possibility that the background CO\u2009(5\u20134) emission measured by Z-Spec at APEX was contaminated by foreground CO\u2009(3\u20132) emission. This work makes use of the previously detected lines in addition to recent observations of CO\u2009J<sub>up</sub>\u00a0=\u00a0[3,6] transitions to remove the ambiguities mentioned. The new observations are described in the following subsections.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=133989592 id=\"133989592\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-1>2.1 APEX</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The instrument suite available at the Atacama Pathfinder EXperiment (APEX) has contributed strongly toward the understanding of H1429\u22120028, giving the initial redshift determination of the system and detecting four CO transitions. The Z-Spec observations targeting the CO transitions J\u00a0=\u00a04\u20133 and 5\u20134 were already described in detail in M14. Here, we proceed to describe the more recent SEPIA Band\u00a05 and SHeFI APEX2 observations.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=133989594 id=\"133989594\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-1-1>2.1.1 SEPIA Band\u00a05</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The CO\u2009(3\u20132) and CS\u2009(7\u20136) transitions were targeted with APEX/SEPIA-Band\u00a05 between 2016 May 25 and June 5 (097.A\u20130995, PI: Messias). The lower side (signal) band was tuned to 170\u00a0GHz to cover the two lines of interest, putting the upper side (image) band at 182\u00a0GHz. The observations were conducted under precipitable water vapor (PWV)\u00a0\u223c\u00a03\u00a0mm (ranging from 2.6 to 5.1\u00a0mm between 2016 \u2009May 25 and June 1, and 1.3\u20131.7\u00a0mm on 2016 June 5) using either Jupiter or Mars as calibrators. A standard observing strategy was adopted (wobbler switching with a 50\u00a0arcmin amplitude, at a frequency of 0.5\u00a0Hz). The total time on source was 5.1\u00a0h. The data were reduced with <span class=\"small-caps\">class</span> (a <span class=\"small-caps\">gildas</span><sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn1\" data-open=\"fn1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">1</a></sup> task). The rms uncertainty on the final co-added spectrum is 0.3\u00a0mK (12\u00a0mJy) at a spectral resolution of 100\u00a0km\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup>. The adopted Kelvin to Jansky conversion factor is 38.4\u00a0Jy/K (Belitsky et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib4\" data-open=\"bib4\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>).</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=133989596 id=\"133989596\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-1-2>2.1.2 SHeFI APEX2</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The CO\u2009(6\u20135) transition was targeted with APEX/SHeFI-APEX2 on 2016 June 5 and between 2016 July 29 and August 4 (097.A-0995, PI: Messias). The lower side (signal) band was tuned to 339.8\u00a0GHz to cover the line of interest and CS\u2009(14\u201313), putting the upper side (image) band at 351.8\u00a0GHz. The observations were conducted under PWV\u00a0=\u00a00.55\u20131.4\u00a0mm, using IRAS\u00a015194\u22125115, SW\u00a0Vir, and SgrB2(N) as calibrators. A standard observing strategy was adopted (wobbler switching with a 50\u00a0arcmin amplitude, at a frequency of 0.5\u00a0Hz). The total time on source was 4\u00a0h. The data were reduced with <span class=\"small-caps\">class</span> (a <span class=\"small-caps\">gildas</span> task). The rms uncertainty on the final co-added spectrum is 0.6\u00a0mK (24\u00a0mJy) at a spectral resolution of 100\u00a0km\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup>. The adopted Kelvin to Jansky conversion factor is 40.8\u00a0Jy/K following the procedure reported in the APEX website.<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn2\" data-open=\"fn2\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">2</a></sup></p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=133989598 id=\"133989598\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3>3 RESULTS</h2>\r\n                    <h3 scrollto-destination=133989599 id=\"133989599\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-1>3.1 Properties of targeted lines</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Altogether, three chemical species (C, CO, and CS) and nine transitions have been targeted thus far (M14 and this work). Of these, only CS\u2009(7\u20136) and CS(14\u201313), observed by APEX, were not detected, as expected by the depths of these observations. Also, since CO\u2009(5\u20134) has not been spectrally resolved thus far, and because of the possibility of foreground line contamination (Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec1-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec1-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">1.1</a>), this transition is left out of the analysis. Figs\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a> and\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig3\" data-open=\"fig3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a> show the newly targeted CO transitions J\u00a0=\u00a03\u20132 and 6\u20135 as observed by SEPIA-Band\u00a05 and SHeFI-APEX2, respectively.</p>                        <a id=\"133989601\" scrollto-destination=\"133989601\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig2\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure\u00a02.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/486/2/10.1093_mnras_stz945/1/m_stz945fig2.jpeg?Expires=1611465158&amp;Signature=s8dp75uoAwWHmM6ffE4l~hPrkXT4aXDXNh9B9uU8cX4zW6ZFpQAIarJ8qWaVzNDLqypjaSMy2wwp4SnEanbTukXuI~foBqB1OqiGeky2CMNMydOS2bGko5VmTkzi~hNVZP-kPY-sRPE8dGdJP7IfWXwwPktQHQKipC8~hZ1BYgU6AnPAJmNBN0Rh4it43zTJXSIiJ4hObyJhfc1SdgdfNq5ZdS~9j6RPkalv4JsSBpwpr8PN-3kwdb350nEKg91ic-ThuUiu5Nl0BdKM4UVBGsvvsSC466d13dGNtJ1KkD9wNpWwTBiibXqb-VLv5usWaTXjX0SQC7ZGRM2Jhcqhdw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"The SEPIA-Band\u00a05 spectrum targeting CO\u2009(3\u20132) transition. The shaded grey region shows the \u00b11\u03c3 uncertainty.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz945fig2.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/133989601/stz945fig2.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz945fig2.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"133989601\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/486/2/10.1093_mnras_stz945/1/stz945fig2.jpeg?Expires=1611465158&Signature=RZvIdG9wFokaPOf4qyDdT5PXD1uhDUqkUGiNz-0JMcurrqE2L~khDbnDd6EkzJTxJEJqvnMcLjwLEeoBTpyHI6pWnC~wZzoWLgrJ45eTvAgEFUb1okgeNUFoO4epTXckSMCj-URMzKxy7yNxdqi4KAJJRmPaelmUwZV98fFK6SfFYeQ7gWxpCsS1OR9Bs78iLjROM6EDqAje36APtso9-3ZMcxPGYY68VzkpB7AuYlkITX83jj9FMvxD2Kpd0~709SQ1k9QhqAJOKHe2xmd1lkkR0Oe96ZsafdZTI-z8nceQe~OvcxuZBVmJIb2~paxc-n8wS3WjBRW6A-vXWV5yIg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=133989601&ar=5475133&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz945fig2.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">The SEPIA-Band\u00a05 spectrum targeting CO\u2009(3\u20132) transition. The shaded grey region shows the \u00b11\u03c3 uncertainty.</p></div></div>                        <a id=\"133989602\" scrollto-destination=\"133989602\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig3\" class=\"fig targeting CO\u2009(6\u20135) transition.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig3\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure\u00a03.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/486/2/10.1093_mnras_stz945/1/m_stz945fig3.jpeg?Expires=1611465158&amp;Signature=HJeLch7Aq7FmWeLv0jE9rwGYHMlImExQFTDHh4DXCadOslYDaQ~QuMFRzcm3EgngBhLgcV1P8eeNp9yzmiaoyRsl72FqB9TA2qWCTopn8boZ4uHFDlX7sy98UHntEv3KSYSFn556PwIi2Sydyxs5MVqjCSUBcUvjnt52w04~Yl4IQUfRdIocV-UY96KuTPHb8uiJ3fbULotXay1wWhaBhROfbVBZ2zWVruRxxw5zeORIDBHHcDT9BgI7rc3f40dR8B7KbvwmQ7WPJTeKpxo1sFjX9ce8ELiztTdYIN6GzEVlZKQYFj92OKcb6AQELS8DQLQqntDq-JSYPZZwILyrWQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"The same as in Fig.\u00a02, but for the SHeFI-APEX2 spectrum targeting CO\u2009(6\u20135) transition.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz945fig3.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/133989602/stz945fig3.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz945fig3.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"133989602\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/486/2/10.1093_mnras_stz945/1/stz945fig3.jpeg?Expires=1611465158&Signature=pdFyMraVe0nRY~HJE5LTlLDpDHKfSm5STlOT3m8kVovSc9iMhravyhQI40r89ijHlNcMW2pvpYY8qwsVAb31hIx5zwEPxMb0BnxtyZMGyLxKoTuPcoLiYWrx1PKA2buxpVnCup~Yf1g1HKHXIdKpURXjXUaDvOBVnOyWZJGLSH1h7Z4HCG88Hs2qm5W-xvXZx~8bazWbJP4shUu1DMhqmU84Q2~mPGHqqdOChX2NFRsxqGoEIZIO7wb-UfXUjXgO4CtImKYYVPTIMhnNUShQ1vTAgUxTRux16KRpHeVQRGGYZCd9Zbz0H~3icVii1T1s4zGsBxIxNHeO7m6C2HHmag__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=133989602&ar=5475133&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz945fig3.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">The same as in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>, but for the SHeFI-APEX2 spectrum targeting CO\u2009(6\u20135) transition.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig4\" data-open=\"fig4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a> compares the line profiles of the CO transitions detected to date. As already mentioned in M14, the J\u00a0=\u00a02\u20131 and 4\u20133 transitions show a double-peak or plateau line profile. These new APEX observations actually follow this scenario, where the blueshifted component is stronger at low-J transitions (and almost absent at J\u00a0=\u00a06\u20135), while the redshifted one is stronger at high-J transitions. This could be a consequence of the red component being more excited than the blue one as a result of the merger. Henceforth, these blue and red velocity components are referred to as components <span class=\"small-caps\">i</span> and <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>, respectively.</p>                        <a id=\"133989604\" scrollto-destination=\"133989604\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig4\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure\u00a04.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/486/2/10.1093_mnras_stz945/1/m_stz945fig4.jpeg?Expires=1611465158&amp;Signature=vrqSO9--SpDcDtFKnIei73Jmz9r1wb4WnsNNsW9tnpPWDlJuqZB2aEvQSplHDmVlvSbvTc9t9VcHdeUKgZA~LmyY71Tsn~oWMOurA8rgWzCee7oDi~4pTDVo4IUst7wEQPv-nRdpya4U~4DZ2QDdYJW5oomlw3FWnoWEiqg88dYWUZ8tsLAlHDV4z-BM7CdWzwvcKslJwIpZwt41p9lwuoZ9CwDz80gKsnvfelaGqGKBc1aTmS98L1d~7ehNjqBhMJBng6nMf1i5giKE2SnT3RkSQ44rWmzlQz6n4kjzSF5yHRyVvl48OZvYj3U1DexHWuseM850HnFpsnAE8x3s4A__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Line profile comparison between the spectrally resolved CO transitions detected to date. In each panel, CO\u2009(2\u20131) is used as reference to ease comparison with CO\u2009J\u00a0=\u00a03\u20132 (left-hand panel), 4\u20133 (middle left), 6\u20135 (middle right), and [C\u2009i]\u20093P1\u22123P0. The line fluxes are normalized to the line peaks. The velocity frame is set to zsp\u00a0=\u00a01.027. The J\u00a0=\u00a04\u20133 is displayed at a \u223c25\u00a0km\u00a0s\u22121 spectral resolution, J\u00a0=\u00a02\u20131 and [C\u2009i] at \u223c40\u00a0km\u00a0s\u22121, while J\u00a0=\u00a03\u20132 and 6\u20135 at \u223c100\u00a0km\u00a0s\u22121. This figure shows that there are up to three detected components comprising the line profile in this system: two central main ones blueshifted and redshifted, and another one redshifted to ${\\sim }500$\u00a0km\u00a0s\u22121. The latter cannot be assessed in the [C\u2009i] transition since it has been flagged due to sky-line contamination (shaded regions).\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz945fig4.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/133989604/stz945fig4.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz945fig4.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"133989604\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/486/2/10.1093_mnras_stz945/1/stz945fig4.jpeg?Expires=1611465158&Signature=0i9ncyIcFmYLHeOeODEamR-Log7us3DnbsWhnvZb614tAdHGpDPGP0d6ZOr4G4HU~c-5JK~Be67lr2-Mtv-1Wg4oa4cht1d5GwuQ85gdoMDlpdbRJ0ZMyN4oNGRiyjd8CFhtwKEaam8EDvBuk-zek5cHcr0PqKoioBqUd7n5~bv3hDkffSckUBtMdI7mMh-h-5c5ybranDEknXgLwYccSF62Nu2K4SIhdYmVhosMshCVyfTg7Z78n9rJ7DSFOIc9EtLTvXOsOdsXDoyG0neL3xbwwMF1aeN8~t8NyoM9LnZ463vLgibG4cFV7nyRWJoc1QpxNLgHNdP0TqEN3~ew3A__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=133989604&ar=5475133&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz945fig4.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Line profile comparison between the spectrally resolved CO transitions detected to date. In each panel, CO\u2009(2\u20131) is used as reference to ease comparison with CO\u2009J\u00a0=\u00a03\u20132 (left-hand panel), 4\u20133 (middle left), 6\u20135 (middle right), and [C\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">i</span>]\u2009<sup>3</sup><em>P</em><sub>1</sub>\u2212<sup>3</sup><em>P</em><sub>0</sub>. The line fluxes are normalized to the line peaks. The velocity frame is set to <em>z</em><sub>sp</sub>\u00a0=\u00a01.027. The J\u00a0=\u00a04\u20133 is displayed at a \u223c25\u00a0km\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup> spectral resolution, J\u00a0=\u00a02\u20131 and [C\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">i</span>] at \u223c40\u00a0km\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup>, while J\u00a0=\u00a03\u20132 and 6\u20135 at \u223c100\u00a0km\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup>. This figure shows that there are up to three detected components comprising the line profile in this system: two central main ones blueshifted and redshifted, and another one redshifted to <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${\\sim }500$|</span>\u00a0km\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup>. The latter cannot be assessed in the [C\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">i</span>] transition since it has been flagged due to sky-line contamination (shaded regions).</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig4\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure\u00a04.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/486/2/10.1093_mnras_stz945/1/m_stz945fig4.jpeg?Expires=1611465158&amp;Signature=vrqSO9--SpDcDtFKnIei73Jmz9r1wb4WnsNNsW9tnpPWDlJuqZB2aEvQSplHDmVlvSbvTc9t9VcHdeUKgZA~LmyY71Tsn~oWMOurA8rgWzCee7oDi~4pTDVo4IUst7wEQPv-nRdpya4U~4DZ2QDdYJW5oomlw3FWnoWEiqg88dYWUZ8tsLAlHDV4z-BM7CdWzwvcKslJwIpZwt41p9lwuoZ9CwDz80gKsnvfelaGqGKBc1aTmS98L1d~7ehNjqBhMJBng6nMf1i5giKE2SnT3RkSQ44rWmzlQz6n4kjzSF5yHRyVvl48OZvYj3U1DexHWuseM850HnFpsnAE8x3s4A__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Line profile comparison between the spectrally resolved CO transitions detected to date. In each panel, CO\u2009(2\u20131) is used as reference to ease comparison with CO\u2009J\u00a0=\u00a03\u20132 (left-hand panel), 4\u20133 (middle left), 6\u20135 (middle right), and [C\u2009i]\u20093P1\u22123P0. The line fluxes are normalized to the line peaks. The velocity frame is set to zsp\u00a0=\u00a01.027. The J\u00a0=\u00a04\u20133 is displayed at a \u223c25\u00a0km\u00a0s\u22121 spectral resolution, J\u00a0=\u00a02\u20131 and [C\u2009i] at \u223c40\u00a0km\u00a0s\u22121, while J\u00a0=\u00a03\u20132 and 6\u20135 at \u223c100\u00a0km\u00a0s\u22121. This figure shows that there are up to three detected components comprising the line profile in this system: two central main ones blueshifted and redshifted, and another one redshifted to ${\\sim }500$\u00a0km\u00a0s\u22121. The latter cannot be assessed in the [C\u2009i] transition since it has been flagged due to sky-line contamination (shaded regions).\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz945fig4.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/133989604/stz945fig4.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz945fig4.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"133989604\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/486/2/10.1093_mnras_stz945/1/stz945fig4.jpeg?Expires=1611465158&Signature=0i9ncyIcFmYLHeOeODEamR-Log7us3DnbsWhnvZb614tAdHGpDPGP0d6ZOr4G4HU~c-5JK~Be67lr2-Mtv-1Wg4oa4cht1d5GwuQ85gdoMDlpdbRJ0ZMyN4oNGRiyjd8CFhtwKEaam8EDvBuk-zek5cHcr0PqKoioBqUd7n5~bv3hDkffSckUBtMdI7mMh-h-5c5ybranDEknXgLwYccSF62Nu2K4SIhdYmVhosMshCVyfTg7Z78n9rJ7DSFOIc9EtLTvXOsOdsXDoyG0neL3xbwwMF1aeN8~t8NyoM9LnZ463vLgibG4cFV7nyRWJoc1QpxNLgHNdP0TqEN3~ew3A__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=133989604&ar=5475133&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz945fig4.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Line profile comparison between the spectrally resolved CO transitions detected to date. In each panel, CO\u2009(2\u20131) is used as reference to ease comparison with CO\u2009J\u00a0=\u00a03\u20132 (left-hand panel), 4\u20133 (middle left), 6\u20135 (middle right), and [C\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">i</span>]\u2009<sup>3</sup><em>P</em><sub>1</sub>\u2212<sup>3</sup><em>P</em><sub>0</sub>. The line fluxes are normalized to the line peaks. The velocity frame is set to <em>z</em><sub>sp</sub>\u00a0=\u00a01.027. The J\u00a0=\u00a04\u20133 is displayed at a \u223c25\u00a0km\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup> spectral resolution, J\u00a0=\u00a02\u20131 and [C\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">i</span>] at \u223c40\u00a0km\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup>, while J\u00a0=\u00a03\u20132 and 6\u20135 at \u223c100\u00a0km\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup>. This figure shows that there are up to three detected components comprising the line profile in this system: two central main ones blueshifted and redshifted, and another one redshifted to <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${\\sim }500$|</span>\u00a0km\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup>. The latter cannot be assessed in the [C\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">i</span>] transition since it has been flagged due to sky-line contamination (shaded regions).</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">Interestingly, the additional flux at even higher velocities (<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">\u2060|${\\sim }500$|</span>\u00a0km\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup>, also mentioned in M14; component <span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span> henceforth) matches the excess flux seen at <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${\\sim }500$|</span>\u00a0km\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup> in the J\u00a0=\u00a06\u20135 spectrum. This could be evidence for a shock-induced component, like an outflow. Because of this result, we revisited the <em>Hubble Space Telescope</em> (<em>HST</em>) grism data assessing any possible emission from the arc-like feature external to the Einstein ring (best seen in <em>HST</em>/Wide Field Camera 3 (WFC3)-<em>F110W</em> imaging), in search of evidence of a velocity match between that component and the redshifted one reported here. However, due to the depth of the data and to neighbouring source contamination, no emission is observed. The location and morphology of this feature are addressed later in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3-3\"></span><a href=\"#sec3-3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3.3</a>.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=133989606 id=\"133989606\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-2>3.2 Spectral line decomposition</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The spectral decomposition of the line profiles into the three possible spectral components mentioned in the previous section was made in a train-and-fit approach. First, a three-Gaussian fit to the spatially integrated CO\u2009(4\u20133) spectrum was pursued as a training step by making use of the <span class=\"small-caps\">python</span> implementation of the affine-invariant ensemble sampler for Markov chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) proposed by Goodman\u00a0&amp;\u00a0Weare (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib30\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib30\" data-open=\"bib30\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>), <span class=\"small-caps\">emcee</span> (Foreman-Mackey et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib23\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib23\" data-open=\"bib23\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>). This transition was chosen being the one with the highest signal-to-noise ratio allowing for a better line profile characterization, and the result can be seen in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig5\" data-open=\"fig5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5</a>. The training-derived values of the three centroid velocities were kept fixed while fitting the remainder of the spectrally resolved CO transition spectra. The training-derived Gaussian full width at half-maximum (FWHM) values of each component were considered as first guesses. Based on the line profile discussion in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec3-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3.1</a> (see also Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig4\" data-open=\"fig4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a>), the flux contribution of each velocity component to each spectrum total flux of a given J\u00a0\u2192\u00a0J\u00a0\u2212\u00a01 rotational transition (<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">\u2060|$\\mathcal {C}^i_{\\rm J,J-1} = {S^i/S^{\\rm TOT}}$|\u2060</span>, where <em>S</em><sup><em>i</em></sup> is the velocity-integrated flux of a given velocity component <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$i\\equiv [{\\rm I,\\,II,\\,III}]$|\u2060</span>, and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${S^{\\rm TOT}}$|</span> the total velocity-integrated flux) had to comply with the following priors: <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathcal {C}^{\\rm I}_{21} &gt; \\mathcal {C}^{\\rm I}_{32} &gt; \\mathcal {C}^{\\rm I}_{43} &gt; \\mathcal {C}^{\\rm I}_{65}$|\u2060</span>, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathcal {C}^{\\rm II,III}_{21} &lt; \\mathcal {C}^{\\rm II,III}_{32} &lt; \\mathcal {C}^{\\rm II,III}_{43} &lt; \\mathcal {C}^{\\rm II,III}_{65}$|\u2060</span>. Note that the <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathcal {C}_{43}$|</span> values are those corresponding to the 50th percentile reported from the training step. While fitting the [C\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">i</span>]\u00a0<sup>3</sup><em>P</em><sub>1</sub>\u2212<sup>3</sup><em>P</em><sub>0</sub> profile, both the component centroid velocities and FWHMs were fixed to the 50th percentiles reported from the training step. This was done since, although the line profile shows a plateau, it also reveals a sharp break at \u223c180\u00a0km\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup> and no extra assumptions on the relative component contribution can be adopted like in the other CO transitions.<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn3\" data-open=\"fn3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">3</a></sup> Because of sky-line contamination, component III is not observable in the [C\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">i</span>] transition.</p>                        <a id=\"133989608\" scrollto-destination=\"133989608\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig5\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure\u00a05.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/486/2/10.1093_mnras_stz945/1/m_stz945fig5.jpeg?Expires=1611465158&amp;Signature=IRUWo1IsyQPCZbhj5K0LXe0Q0VqW5YUsHlUBGOAIxWCURCfL4-xcp5wmMa~jE7~ApL7IN8NqS1ARK0k3hziZhdbZ1PVqXylu2ZlMw1~G8a09n1pFVYtrR9TJz3Eg6BtN7h2GA6suq~4-xSECdj-WzY0PzjdYj~lmABDRsjRhqQeoB3bRo6UFsC50rZQdlvivrTKJSlcqR0K35zHE2h0GHhDHjlhNcBqb4U-RGNyLcB4M7z6IQhPMD3MhbPOPLqO6rgSe8ZuSY~QSAbbUXWqy0crmvwVDJUcmnddd~HuI-SiXU7Yyd-PdVPEFSBOoeQNglgBu9IazHNdFj9zgp2ZCVQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Spectral decomposition of the CO\u2009(4\u20133) transition. The solid black histogram shows the observed spectrum. The solid blue line represents the 50th percentile spectral fit, with each of the three components shown individually as dotted blue lines. The grey thin solid lines are 100 randomly chosen MCMC samples. This analysis served as a training step before fitting the remainder spectrally resolved transitions (Fig.\u00a06). The error level per channel relative to peak is \u223c1.2\u00a0per\u00a0cent.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz945fig5.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/133989608/stz945fig5.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz945fig5.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"133989608\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/486/2/10.1093_mnras_stz945/1/stz945fig5.jpeg?Expires=1611465158&Signature=IqSuLlfzTDQyMEo--zejA7m0ZQTZMH2Bz0xj7eBIJv8N3xZVPE8ZMl8d4017kEW0lJSM73k5QDp7UZNHbg5ye-SW1FKgzf5OCxeAPi~uKlUFG8MoXglqL4pdCLxkxItM508HNQg~tx7gZLui9ftEJuxWeCLk-0-FLj4ZgQCkrizA-lQhxCcKWd3cCE4Jgff8GOwDZ9cMTvruOzi11~MwH09tHK-il10M6Y~EoN91hKjPQAanMOwaibbdtDGFQh8Ee9vBvLTCLKMmX8NhOXcsYAUoR6-B4kKFKk6WH2dlH-MWd8hBIRw~iCnu1JLK2Bc9-SHtSbkSUCIQ6zbU5TrwHQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=133989608&ar=5475133&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz945fig5.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Spectral decomposition of the CO\u2009(4\u20133) transition. The solid black histogram shows the observed spectrum. The solid blue line represents the 50th percentile spectral fit, with each of the three components shown individually as dotted blue lines. The grey thin solid lines are 100 randomly chosen MCMC samples. This analysis served as a training step before fitting the remainder spectrally resolved transitions (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a>). The error level per channel relative to peak is \u223c1.2\u00a0per\u00a0cent.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig5\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure\u00a05.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/486/2/10.1093_mnras_stz945/1/m_stz945fig5.jpeg?Expires=1611465158&amp;Signature=IRUWo1IsyQPCZbhj5K0LXe0Q0VqW5YUsHlUBGOAIxWCURCfL4-xcp5wmMa~jE7~ApL7IN8NqS1ARK0k3hziZhdbZ1PVqXylu2ZlMw1~G8a09n1pFVYtrR9TJz3Eg6BtN7h2GA6suq~4-xSECdj-WzY0PzjdYj~lmABDRsjRhqQeoB3bRo6UFsC50rZQdlvivrTKJSlcqR0K35zHE2h0GHhDHjlhNcBqb4U-RGNyLcB4M7z6IQhPMD3MhbPOPLqO6rgSe8ZuSY~QSAbbUXWqy0crmvwVDJUcmnddd~HuI-SiXU7Yyd-PdVPEFSBOoeQNglgBu9IazHNdFj9zgp2ZCVQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Spectral decomposition of the CO\u2009(4\u20133) transition. The solid black histogram shows the observed spectrum. The solid blue line represents the 50th percentile spectral fit, with each of the three components shown individually as dotted blue lines. The grey thin solid lines are 100 randomly chosen MCMC samples. This analysis served as a training step before fitting the remainder spectrally resolved transitions (Fig.\u00a06). The error level per channel relative to peak is \u223c1.2\u00a0per\u00a0cent.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz945fig5.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/133989608/stz945fig5.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz945fig5.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"133989608\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/486/2/10.1093_mnras_stz945/1/stz945fig5.jpeg?Expires=1611465158&Signature=IqSuLlfzTDQyMEo--zejA7m0ZQTZMH2Bz0xj7eBIJv8N3xZVPE8ZMl8d4017kEW0lJSM73k5QDp7UZNHbg5ye-SW1FKgzf5OCxeAPi~uKlUFG8MoXglqL4pdCLxkxItM508HNQg~tx7gZLui9ftEJuxWeCLk-0-FLj4ZgQCkrizA-lQhxCcKWd3cCE4Jgff8GOwDZ9cMTvruOzi11~MwH09tHK-il10M6Y~EoN91hKjPQAanMOwaibbdtDGFQh8Ee9vBvLTCLKMmX8NhOXcsYAUoR6-B4kKFKk6WH2dlH-MWd8hBIRw~iCnu1JLK2Bc9-SHtSbkSUCIQ6zbU5TrwHQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=133989608&ar=5475133&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz945fig5.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Spectral decomposition of the CO\u2009(4\u20133) transition. The solid black histogram shows the observed spectrum. The solid blue line represents the 50th percentile spectral fit, with each of the three components shown individually as dotted blue lines. The grey thin solid lines are 100 randomly chosen MCMC samples. This analysis served as a training step before fitting the remainder spectrally resolved transitions (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a>). The error level per channel relative to peak is \u223c1.2\u00a0per\u00a0cent.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a> shows the results of this fitting approach, while Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a> reports on the velocity-integrated fluxes of each component at each CO and [C\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">i</span>] transitions. The <span class=\"small-caps\">i, ii</span>, and <span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span> refer to each component ordered by increasing centroid velocity (<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">\u2060|$v_\\mathrm{ c}^{\\mathrm{ I}} = -130_{-6}^{+6}$|</span>\u00a0km\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup>, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$v_\\mathrm{ c}^{\\rm II} = 131_{-5}^{+5}$|</span>\u00a0km\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup>, and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$v_\\mathrm{ c}^{\\rm III} = 500_{-30}^{+20}$|</span>\u00a0km\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup> as measured in CO\u2009J\u00a0=\u00a04\u20133). Note that components <span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span> and <span class=\"small-caps\">i</span> in CO\u00a0(2\u20131) and (6\u20135), respectively, are allowed to be zero, i.e. not to be present, yet the analysis shows that these components are detected at the 3.2\u03c3 and 1.4\u03c3 levels (0.9<sub>\u22120.3</sub> and 11<sub>\u22128</sub>\u00a0Jy\u00a0km\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup>), respectively.</p>                        <a id=\"133989610\" scrollto-destination=\"133989610\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig6\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure\u00a06.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/486/2/10.1093_mnras_stz945/1/m_stz945fig6.jpeg?Expires=1611465158&amp;Signature=vgSWMi5cCPZbu76YE0wnAFhPi54OtwZF1QsI-s9CbYrTB1wmL4OJ60B9K8eYM8kDC96BkZmXXhK3Ch5fdjSsytOd9A8LBDKJTjTsyUjCcZeXasKuaNuNsidkQnzWI0LYVFt8auqXUyMjaM59i-fUPUEN9MOpblFp7TzzXEmGKvul6SjLpLRtDkhVasJQT2FL5iEUrwMBDvRwDuSE2VS4UWsVDCn4paqz9cfIK9THyBMExFitw4FeUUB0461YAdmRTwH6NhGWNySv7~3k7BwESDh4d2sXxVc-mUMg4jNkxvO4rdbb6HLZ25OVhyTN2JNOv8ClKhMJwZpfe201cTEB8g__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Spectral decomposition of the other spectrally resolved CO and [C\u2009i] transitions. The solid black histograms show the observed spectra normalized to maximum flux for comparison purposes. The solid blue line represents the 50th percentile spectral fit, with each of the three components shown individually as dotted blue lines. The grey thin solid lines are 100 randomly chosen MCMC samples. The training step was done by fitting the CO\u00a0(4\u20133) transition (Fig.\u00a05). The central velocities of each spectral component were kept fixed. The error level per channel relative to peak is about: 2.6\u00a0per\u00a0cent (left-hand panel), 20\u00a0per\u00a0cent (middle-left panel), 22\u00a0per\u00a0cent (middle-right panel), and 3.2\u00a0per\u00a0cent (right-hand panel). Again, note that the shaded regions in the [C\u2009i] panel show the velocity ranges contaminated by atmospheric line.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz945fig6.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/133989610/stz945fig6.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz945fig6.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"133989610\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/486/2/10.1093_mnras_stz945/1/stz945fig6.jpeg?Expires=1611465158&Signature=VsektM58l8KLcfP3mmFf1zPiWgTFOFE1ikRq51PllQXFBtmQuvLrLwTFWLFM3zaNumH-a1QM9o4P9Vt4n2q2dNp7I6yW8Pv7EzPSldqEF79Vm9gwF8sUMLBn8EMg8hujyk~t1MbWZDmxy0XEpM13iCZRRAENIL7hjVOJ201Gozgk88~g6wHY22GbwwA0HsKfnUKJHssyLC1jxj9kyswyKe5V8gbZrZ~qyrTjXPeSdgrA94pYN0k5d3YZDacBuSqQ5JpUJsuTsxS09cmNq52nMtpuLRhFENCxeNiPBZj3QQB-ss7DuWCUjklta9QG~-U1mbmRHyx3f49fmquBGKNSMA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=133989610&ar=5475133&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz945fig6.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Spectral decomposition of the other spectrally resolved CO and [C\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">i</span>] transitions. The grey thin solid lines are 100 randomly chosen MCMC samples. Again, note that the shaded regions in the [C\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">i</span>] panel show the velocity ranges contaminated by atmospheric line.</p></div></div>                        <a class=\"table-wrap-foot\"><span id=\"fn-tblf1\"></span><div content-id=\"tblf1\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Note</em>. The central velocities of each component as measured in CO\u2009(4\u20133) are <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$v_\\mathrm{ c}^{\\rm I} = -130_{-6}^{+6}$|</span>\u00a0km\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup>, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$v_\\mathrm{ c}^{\\rm II} = 131_{-5}^{+5}$|</span>\u00a0km\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup>, and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$v_\\mathrm{ c}^{\\rm III} = 500_{-30}^{+20}$|</span>\u00a0km\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup>.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-tblf2\"></span><div content-id=\"tblf2\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>a</em></sup>Values are those retrieved by integrating the observed spectra from \u2013500 to 1000\u00a0km\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup> in CO transitions and to 500\u00a0km\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup> in the [C\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">i</span>] transition.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-tblf3\"></span><div content-id=\"tblf3\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>b</em></sup>The FWHM values for each of the two components in [C\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">i</span>]\u00a0<sup>3</sup><em>P</em><sub>1</sub>\u2212<sup>3</sup><em>P</em><sub>0</sub> were fixed to those measured in CO\u00a0(4\u20133).</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/133989611\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">The spectral\u2013spatial decomposition of the three components was also pursued on a pixel-by-pixel basis (i.e. not in the visibility plane). Again, a three-Gaussian fit to the spatially integrated CO(4\u20133) spectrum was used as a training step. The training-derived values of the centroid velocity and Gaussian FWHM of each component were used as reference for each spectrum fit in each cube pixel, while the relative amplitudes were computed independently for each cube pixel. Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig7\" data-open=\"fig7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">7</a> shows the result of this spatial\u2013spectral decomposition via the velocity-integrated flux maps (moment-0) of each studied component. The spatial distributions are distinct between the three, hence coming from different regions and this may result in distinct magnifications.</p>                        <a id=\"133989613\" scrollto-destination=\"133989613\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig7\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure\u00a07.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/486/2/10.1093_mnras_stz945/1/m_stz945fig7.jpeg?Expires=1611465158&amp;Signature=26ISVvrTb73Ihlspmv59LRP22C7Q3CLVbh8Rzw2TlY047Jhnl66rOHzjdPDiRNsjYtfnZdJbUL2C-JqczveT-rKFQcVdGIfAk0WJ8y0JInhugHMRW6eltFpCN798qc1BAGeqxa-fc0QxbpYAGH5169bm3QeIF54hYIfVtpLJe8rQFfuUhnFpt1fthhu53KRQjEJHvdLPa~FerKtz1HWMMj4rtt638D7E6DPX4xU06LbNbwOin99tdh~GNmcmyYXB7p9H5XWM5WFCpBSj7mmeOgWRr8b7~FcbBY~JUq~YS3LWnwwqGwCJeKZjc1oY5~0wnjnNrKkpxmV7XdYnKp7Mnw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"A spectral\u2013spatial decomposition of the three spectral components comprising the CO\u2009(4\u20133) emission. The grey-scale image represents the total velocity-integrated flux map (moment-0). The blue contours in the left-hand, middle, and right-hand panels reveal the emission of, respectively, the components with centroids at around \u2212130 (I), 130 (II), and 500 (III)\u00a0km\u00a0s\u22121 away from the systemic velocity. The contour levels are 3\u03c3, 6\u03c3, 12\u03c3, 24\u03c3, and 48\u03c3.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz945fig7.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/133989613/stz945fig7.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz945fig7.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"133989613\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/486/2/10.1093_mnras_stz945/1/stz945fig7.jpeg?Expires=1611465158&Signature=le6XKEIrKZ5OpMlZCJ4jC45TLXw7OKm8hG1~5SpRjmL78dOTzPE246we-1j9xwNzNWW58BIyvDXVUJHkzmOnSXCNPgyWNwH1mWxTJO4ZpT3gtN2F5H75H-LAZIL~XYKNcvj0oX7aixSKSqc00G14fdb2cMYso2LZgzlNrum~CpAdWNts9IMM5aa3NixDpwce8y5J3~Hfbl-sQCCh8c6Ydkymr-4MukM3rXwXy8MaxmzICRVSp~J1RWVYBK9SO1K45KbZ5g88yBrBflbs4r6nWbJs4flhFMEq1ErkdPSQ~gzCcyiquJlFdf7uVq2PcBuwrBmoP8plYy8H1mLVQYw3QA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=133989613&ar=5475133&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz945fig7.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">A spectral\u2013spatial decomposition of the three spectral components comprising the CO\u2009(4\u20133) emission. The contour levels are 3\u03c3, 6\u03c3, 12\u03c3, 24\u03c3, and 48\u03c3.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig7\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure\u00a07.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/486/2/10.1093_mnras_stz945/1/m_stz945fig7.jpeg?Expires=1611465158&amp;Signature=26ISVvrTb73Ihlspmv59LRP22C7Q3CLVbh8Rzw2TlY047Jhnl66rOHzjdPDiRNsjYtfnZdJbUL2C-JqczveT-rKFQcVdGIfAk0WJ8y0JInhugHMRW6eltFpCN798qc1BAGeqxa-fc0QxbpYAGH5169bm3QeIF54hYIfVtpLJe8rQFfuUhnFpt1fthhu53KRQjEJHvdLPa~FerKtz1HWMMj4rtt638D7E6DPX4xU06LbNbwOin99tdh~GNmcmyYXB7p9H5XWM5WFCpBSj7mmeOgWRr8b7~FcbBY~JUq~YS3LWnwwqGwCJeKZjc1oY5~0wnjnNrKkpxmV7XdYnKp7Mnw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"A spectral\u2013spatial decomposition of the three spectral components comprising the CO\u2009(4\u20133) emission. The contour levels are 3\u03c3, 6\u03c3, 12\u03c3, 24\u03c3, and 48\u03c3.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz945fig7.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/133989613/stz945fig7.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz945fig7.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"133989613\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/486/2/10.1093_mnras_stz945/1/stz945fig7.jpeg?Expires=1611465158&Signature=le6XKEIrKZ5OpMlZCJ4jC45TLXw7OKm8hG1~5SpRjmL78dOTzPE246we-1j9xwNzNWW58BIyvDXVUJHkzmOnSXCNPgyWNwH1mWxTJO4ZpT3gtN2F5H75H-LAZIL~XYKNcvj0oX7aixSKSqc00G14fdb2cMYso2LZgzlNrum~CpAdWNts9IMM5aa3NixDpwce8y5J3~Hfbl-sQCCh8c6Ydkymr-4MukM3rXwXy8MaxmzICRVSp~J1RWVYBK9SO1K45KbZ5g88yBrBflbs4r6nWbJs4flhFMEq1ErkdPSQ~gzCcyiquJlFdf7uVq2PcBuwrBmoP8plYy8H1mLVQYw3QA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=133989613&ar=5475133&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz945fig7.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">A spectral\u2013spatial decomposition of the three spectral components comprising the CO\u2009(4\u20133) emission. The grey-scale image represents the total velocity-integrated flux map (moment-0). The blue contours in the left-hand, middle, and right-hand panels reveal the emission of, respectively, the components with centroids at around \u2212130 (I), 130 (II), and 500 (III)\u00a0km\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup> away from the systemic velocity. The contour levels are 3\u03c3, 6\u03c3, 12\u03c3, 24\u03c3, and 48\u03c3.</p></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=133989614 id=\"133989614\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-3>3.3 Differential magnification</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Given the extension and multiplicity of the background system, one may wonder whether differential magnification may occur to some degree. In table\u00a03 of M14, the lensing modelling at the time showed a range in the magnification factor between 5 and 11 depending on the spectral band. Since then, new observations have been obtained at much finer spatial resolution (0.12\u00a0arcsec; Dye et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib21\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib21\" data-open=\"bib21\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>) tracing the dust emission at rest frame 696\u00a0GHz (430\u00a0<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mu {\\rm m}$|\u2060</span>). These allowed an improvement of the lens model, which resulted in a revised magnification factor of 24\u00a0\u00b1\u00a01, twice that reported in M14 (10.8\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.7). Even though the latter was based on slightly lower frequency data (rest frame 474\u00a0GHz or 632\u00a0<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mu {\\rm m}$|\u2060</span>), both are tracing cold dust via the Rayleigh\u2013Jeans tail of the spectrum, hence the difference between the two results from the improvement in the lensing model.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We have thus revised the source reconstruction of the CO\u2009(4\u20133) emission. Specifically, each moment-0 map of the spectral components (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig7\" data-open=\"fig7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">7</a>) was reconstructed separately using the same lens model from Dye et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib21\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib21\" data-open=\"bib21\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>), and AutoLens (Nightingale, Dye\u00a0&amp;\u00a0Massey <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib56\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib56\" data-open=\"bib56\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>) was used as an independent check of the lens parameters. The best-fitting result is seen in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig8\" data-open=\"fig8\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">8</a>, where the source areas (<em>A</em>) by counting the number of pixels in the source plane above 3\u03c3 are found to be <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$A^{\\rm I} = 0.062$|</span>\u00a0arcsec<sup>2</sup> (4.1\u00a0kpc<sup>2</sup>), <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$A^{\\rm II} = 0.039$|</span>\u00a0arcsec<sup>2</sup> (2.6\u00a0kpc<sup>2</sup>), and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$A^{\\rm III} = 0.011$|</span>\u00a0arcsec<sup>2</sup> (0.72\u00a0kpc<sup>2</sup>). This new analysis also implies that the current estimate for the dynamical mass and half-light radius of the NS component in the merger is <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$M_{\\rm dyn} = 5_{-2}^{+3}\\times 10^{10}$|</span>\u00a0M<sub>\u2299</sub> and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$r_{1/2} = 0.7_{-0.3}^{+0.5}$|</span>\u00a0kpc, which are in agreement with the reported values in M14, where the \u2018isotropic virial estimator\u2019 was also assumed: <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${M_{\\rm dyn}} = 2.8\\times 10^5 (\\Delta v_{\\rm FWHM})^2 r_{1/2}$|\u2060</span>, where <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${}[{M_{\\rm dyn}}] = \\mathrm{ M}_\\odot$|\u2060</span>, \u0394<em>v</em><sub>FWHM</sub> is the CO(4\u20133) FWHM, and <em>r</em><sub>1/2</sub> is the half-light radius in units of kpc.</p>                        <a id=\"133989617\" scrollto-destination=\"133989617\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig8\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure\u00a08.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/486/2/10.1093_mnras_stz945/1/m_stz945fig8.jpeg?Expires=1611465158&amp;Signature=vPlc7ARh7JnuVOc8QYgzFVKuHuI5-1v3l3qtI~RD0i~bbJSLFOGRJjbLFWtx2eW849kcM5wgNb-eTcV4vXEt2LQaXwDXejtzkZROiNI4GxXe9KoGDOjCOBNZReXzMObJpGgmzUnciBeASaom3BdJt3eAvn15Ub6AZ~DeO67dChBxS3Vb9PV6xowgX7qITkBO6thwctWu7Rhrbjir9j6nVjMCVXnJOLukiK-8GHg3RWLrhGqkYVWON1yZbGr~OOZ53mp3gcJDRx9nxvlM0eh4J7nCB5I7qdcLahE9TInaCJSEOQ51fuJ83uRB~8-yLkdCOkCcqAATCSBmznsFxUYENQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"The three panels show the spectral\u2013spatial decomposition in the $0.8\\times 0.8\\,$\u00a0arcsec2 source plane of the three spectral components comprising the CO\u2009(4\u20133) emission. The blue contours in the left, middle-left, and middle-right panels reveal the CO\u2009(4\u20133) emission of, respectively, the components with centroids at $-130_{-6}^{+6}$\u00a0km\u00a0s\u22121 (i), $+131_{-5}^{+5}$\u00a0km\u00a0s\u22121 (ii), and $+500_{-30}^{+20}$\u00a0km\u00a0s\u22121 (iii) away of the systemic velocity.
