These show how the magnification evolves with cumulative source flux (indicated as fraction of total flux), which is estimated by gradually summing source plane pixels in decreasing flux order. It is evident that component III is consistently less magnified than the other two components, which have indistinguishable total magnifications at flux fractions above \u223c0.6 within errors. The total magnifications are the following: <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mu ^{\\rm I} = 15.1\\pm 0.7$|\u2060</span>, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mu ^{\\rm II} = 15.6\\pm 0.4$|\u2060</span>, and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mu ^{\\rm III} = 12\\pm 1$|\u2060</span>.</p>                        <a id=\"133989619\" scrollto-destination=\"133989619\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig9\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure\u00a09.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/486/2/10.1093_mnras_stz945/1/m_stz945fig9.jpeg?Expires=1611465158&amp;Signature=dRS-41rOY7dGFRCr4SMg6lDky8e0tEoBXMwy7HR5XWZG8zO2ZFRh4sQkewuBIywSKOYcQCHB6nsT9MqiG2mQdIK9Jj9P8ge7UGGzP-CFSt2XOO3iNIn~nOKpomUqgMnaggZhBpUvYXNOg9e~3mzuV~Hts5s~Hc3L8tDl3xUTunqmM0gvhKXT2u6Y7VqbjI6avADMbeN0wy5zjZ88IHxgU9sTeijH4QpjRLRpOu~TJTllN1wKUQAOA170B1eZpyn4Gd1TDSRH2yfasiZsKr8kT5C2OfHGhJ~CKVHxVGU9nHiMQRP4xFh7C9t07mhEKjrhCPWo6OlVLsFy3DG8dIoOnQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Assessing the differential magnification in H1429\u22120028. The cumulative source flux (indicated as fraction of total flux) is estimated by gradually summing source plane pixels in decreasing flux order. While components i and ii in CO(4\u20133) are magnified by a comparable amount (\u03bc\u00a0\u223c\u00a015), component iii is less magnified (\u03bc\u00a0\u223c\u00a012). The profile of [C\u2009i]\u20093P1\u22123P0 for the combined emission from components i and ii is also displayed in green, showing no significant difference with respect to CO(4\u20133).\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz945fig9.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/133989619/stz945fig9.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz945fig9.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"133989619\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/486/2/10.1093_mnras_stz945/1/stz945fig9.jpeg?Expires=1611465158&Signature=gieAUpBcmNtGy~7JblAAvlqI7VktjX~h5W3x58rYiB8ikY59xMCy6GpHBtE2vxmD07QEuuSSyp6x-SaVUgZySZ9HIBqCx8tbENTsA-ITZ~KNRABBt2K~iaCLQ7zRkI51oqfV4~j-yJ1EcWMlWYpLGrErRfNLhE1cqPBI92tzDfKRxt8LdhMUuzntZvxifGVj7xPq7bf7aq474ejQ7C8ZakYKdQsJGzxkSbDYrdZMIOMIYEKZ7cNOunPWSv74VugM8kdUoGzVL6trkzm9I2cNj578UFH49czccAWTjowk5irfCPm1DCNESX3PuhTjqQ1Hji1pSvNzp0AUV9rBs3u5fQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=133989619&ar=5475133&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz945fig9.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Assessing the differential magnification in H1429\u22120028. The cumulative source flux (indicated as fraction of total flux) is estimated by gradually summing source plane pixels in decreasing flux order. While components <span class=\"small-caps\">i</span> and <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span> in CO(4\u20133) are magnified by a comparable amount (<em>\u03bc</em>\u00a0\u223c\u00a015), component <span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span> is less magnified (<em>\u03bc</em>\u00a0\u223c\u00a012). The profile of [C\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">i</span>]\u2009<sup>3</sup><em>P</em><sub>1</sub>\u2212<sup>3</sup><em>P</em><sub>0</sub> for the combined emission from components <span class=\"small-caps\">i</span> and <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span> is also displayed in green, showing no significant difference with respect to CO(4\u20133).</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig9\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure\u00a09.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/486/2/10.1093_mnras_stz945/1/m_stz945fig9.jpeg?Expires=1611465158&amp;Signature=dRS-41rOY7dGFRCr4SMg6lDky8e0tEoBXMwy7HR5XWZG8zO2ZFRh4sQkewuBIywSKOYcQCHB6nsT9MqiG2mQdIK9Jj9P8ge7UGGzP-CFSt2XOO3iNIn~nOKpomUqgMnaggZhBpUvYXNOg9e~3mzuV~Hts5s~Hc3L8tDl3xUTunqmM0gvhKXT2u6Y7VqbjI6avADMbeN0wy5zjZ88IHxgU9sTeijH4QpjRLRpOu~TJTllN1wKUQAOA170B1eZpyn4Gd1TDSRH2yfasiZsKr8kT5C2OfHGhJ~CKVHxVGU9nHiMQRP4xFh7C9t07mhEKjrhCPWo6OlVLsFy3DG8dIoOnQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Assessing the differential magnification in H1429\u22120028. The cumulative source flux (indicated as fraction of total flux) is estimated by gradually summing source plane pixels in decreasing flux order. While components i and ii in CO(4\u20133) are magnified by a comparable amount (\u03bc\u00a0\u223c\u00a015), component iii is less magnified (\u03bc\u00a0\u223c\u00a012). The profile of [C\u2009i]\u20093P1\u22123P0 for the combined emission from components i and ii is also displayed in green, showing no significant difference with respect to CO(4\u20133).\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz945fig9.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/133989619/stz945fig9.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz945fig9.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"133989619\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/486/2/10.1093_mnras_stz945/1/stz945fig9.jpeg?Expires=1611465158&Signature=gieAUpBcmNtGy~7JblAAvlqI7VktjX~h5W3x58rYiB8ikY59xMCy6GpHBtE2vxmD07QEuuSSyp6x-SaVUgZySZ9HIBqCx8tbENTsA-ITZ~KNRABBt2K~iaCLQ7zRkI51oqfV4~j-yJ1EcWMlWYpLGrErRfNLhE1cqPBI92tzDfKRxt8LdhMUuzntZvxifGVj7xPq7bf7aq474ejQ7C8ZakYKdQsJGzxkSbDYrdZMIOMIYEKZ7cNOunPWSv74VugM8kdUoGzVL6trkzm9I2cNj578UFH49czccAWTjowk5irfCPm1DCNESX3PuhTjqQ1Hji1pSvNzp0AUV9rBs3u5fQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=133989619&ar=5475133&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz945fig9.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Assessing the differential magnification in H1429\u22120028. The cumulative source flux (indicated as fraction of total flux) is estimated by gradually summing source plane pixels in decreasing flux order. While components <span class=\"small-caps\">i</span> and <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span> in CO(4\u20133) are magnified by a comparable amount (<em>\u03bc</em>\u00a0\u223c\u00a015), component <span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span> is less magnified (<em>\u03bc</em>\u00a0\u223c\u00a012). The profile of [C\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">i</span>]\u2009<sup>3</sup><em>P</em><sub>1</sub>\u2212<sup>3</sup><em>P</em><sub>0</sub> for the combined emission from components <span class=\"small-caps\">i</span> and <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span> is also displayed in green, showing no significant difference with respect to CO(4\u20133).</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">Finally, it is worth assessing the differential magnification between each emission line. The other transition resolved into the ring and knot morphology observed in CO(4\u20133) is [C\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">i</span>]\u2009<sup>3</sup><em>P</em><sub>1</sub>\u2212<sup>3</sup><em>P</em><sub>0</sub>. The same model from Dye et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib21\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib21\" data-open=\"bib21\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>) was applied to the velocity-integrated flux map of [C\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">i</span>]. This time, for the purpose of maximizing signal-to-noise ratio, and since the CO(4\u20133) analysis pointed to no differential magnification between the velocity components <span class=\"small-caps\">i</span> and <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>, both of these were analysed together (i.e. no spectral deblending was considered). The spatial distribution of the emission at &gt;3\u03c3 is displayed in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig8\" data-open=\"fig8\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">8</a>, comprising an area of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$A_{\\rm [CI]} = 0.046$|</span>\u00a0arcsec<sup>2</sup> (3.0\u00a0kpc<sup>2</sup>). The magnification profile is displayed in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig9\" data-open=\"fig9\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">9</a>, where it is seen that it follows those observed in CO(4\u20133) and its total magnification factor is 16.1\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.6.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">As a result, based on the available data, we assume below that the analysis is not affected by differential magnification between velocity components nor between spectral lines. Specifically, we assume that the velocity components <span class=\"small-caps\">i</span> and <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span> are equally magnified and the CO transitions between themselves and with respect to [C\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">i</span>].</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=133989622 id=\"133989622\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-4>3.4 Large velocity gradient analysis</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">In Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3-3\"></span><a href=\"#sec3-3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3.3</a>, we make the case that, within the uncertainties, the differences between the two main spectral components <span class=\"small-caps\">i</span> and <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span> are not affected by differential magnification, but rather from different excitation levels (Daddi et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib17\" data-open=\"bib17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>; Yang et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib90\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib90\" data-open=\"bib90\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>; Ca\u00f1ameras et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib9\" data-open=\"bib9\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). Also, component <span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span> is significantly less magnified and its [C\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">i</span>] emission is unconstrained due to sky-line contamination, preventing a proper analysis of its physical conditions. However, given its brightness, it is expected to account for a relatively minor fraction of the molecular gas budget in the system. Nevertheless, follow-up observations are of interest since this feature will likely help to understand the current stage of evolution of the merger (e.g. if it is confirmed to be an outflow). As a result, this section will focus on the separate analysis of components <span class=\"small-caps\">i</span> and <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span> alone. We note that it does not consider CO\u2009(5\u20134) since it is not spectrally resolved. In the future, high spatial resolution imaging will enable proper multi-J spectral and spatial decomposition of the CO emission as it is shown for CO\u2009(4\u20133) in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3-3\"></span><a href=\"#sec3-3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3.3</a>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">As already mentioned, many transitions were detected thus far towards H1429\u20130028: CO\u2009(J<sub>up</sub>\u00a0=\u00a02, 3, 4, 5, 6), [C\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">i</span>]\u2009(<sup>3</sup><em>P</em><sub>1</sub>\u2212<sup>3</sup><em>P</em><sub>0</sub>), and CS\u2009(10\u20139). The former two species are commonly used to indirectly derive the molecular gas content. While CO is brighter, thus easier to detect, the fine structure system of [C\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">i</span>] is characterized by a simple three-level system easily excited by particle collisions, and is believed to be widespread in giant molecular clouds (Tomassetti et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib80\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib80\" data-open=\"bib80\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>, and references therein). The CS molecule is regarded as a high-density gas tracer, hence it could be used as well, but this retrieved poor results (e.g. the predicted CO SLED overestimated the high-J transitions\u2019 fluxes). This may be a result of CS being detected in a very small region in the system, while CO and C are more extended, which could then result in differential magnification (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig9\" data-open=\"fig9\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">9</a>), further enhancing the difference.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We adopt the large velocity gradient (LVG) formalism to interpret the CO\u2009(J<sub>up</sub>\u00a0=\u00a02, 3, 4, 6) and [C\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">i</span>] SLED by making use of <span class=\"small-caps\">myradex</span>.<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn4\" data-open=\"fn4\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">4</a></sup> An escape probability of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\beta = \\frac{1-\\mathrm{ e}^{-\\tau }}{\\tau }$|</span> is assumed in an expanding spherical geometry. The CMB temperature is 5.53\u00a0K at <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a01.027. The CO line width was set to 262 and 228\u00a0km\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup> for components <span class=\"small-caps\">i</span> and <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>, respectively, in accordance to the values in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>. The CO and C abundances relative to H<sub>2</sub> (small <em>x</em><sub>CO</sub> and <em>x</em><sub>C</sub>) are both assumed to be \u223c10<sup>\u22124</sup>, which already implies that a significant fraction of carbon is locked into CO (Walter et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib86\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib86\" data-open=\"bib86\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>), i.e. the CO emission mostly comes from dense molecular regions (e.g. Wolfire, Hollenbach\u00a0&amp;\u00a0McKee <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib89\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib89\" data-open=\"bib89\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; Narayanan et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib53\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib53\" data-open=\"bib53\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>). The uncertainty in these abundances is further explored in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4-2\"></span><a href=\"#sec4-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">4.2</a>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We have adopted different approaches to estimate the gas temperature (<em>T</em>\u00a0[K]), the molecular number density (<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">\u2060|$n_{\\rm H_2}$|</span>\u00a0[cm<sup>\u22123</sup>]), velocity gradient (d<em>v</em>\u00a0[m\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup>\u00a0pc<sup>\u22121</sup>]), column density (<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">\u2060|$N_{\\rm H_2}$|</span>\u00a0[cm<sup>\u22122</sup>]),<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn5\" data-open=\"fn5\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">5</a></sup> and the molecular gas mass (<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">\u2060|${M_{\\rm H_2}}$|</span>\u00a0[M<sub>\u2299</sub>]), while considering CO and [C\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">i</span>] together. The best-fitting value was obtained by finding the minimum \u03c7<sup>2</sup> value in a grid of line intensity values considering conditions ranging 10\u00a0&lt;\u00a0<em>T</em>\u00a0[K]\u00a0&lt;\u00a01000, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$10^2 &lt; n_{\\rm H_2}\\,[{\\rm cm^{-3}}] &lt; 10^6$|\u2060</span>, and 10<sup>2</sup>\u00a0&lt;\u00a0d<em>v</em>\u00a0[m\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup>\u00a0pc<sup>\u22121</sup>]\u00a0&lt;\u00a010<sup>6</sup>, with log steps of 0.1\u00a0dex. Maximum likelihood (ML; e.g. Zhang et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib91\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib91\" data-open=\"bib91\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>), bootstrapping, and MCMC approaches also adopted this same grid and provided the 16th, 50th, and 84th percentiles. While bootstrapping, a total of 1000 iterations were adopted where, in each one, the observed line flux values were randomly defined to be around the real observed value following a Gaussian distribution with a standard deviation equal to the estimated flux error. This was adopted in all the above approaches, together with a 5 and 10\u00a0per\u00a0cent error in flux added in quadrature to the instrumental error to account for the uncertainty in the absolute flux scaling in CO\u2009(2\u20131) and the remaining transitions, respectively.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">This analysis adopted priors in order to better constrain the results. The H<sub>2</sub> mass should not be larger than the dynamical mass (<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">\u2060|$M{\\rm _{H_2}} &lt; 7.8\\times 10^{10}\\, {\\rm M_\\odot }$|\u2060</span>, +1\u03c3 of the dynamical mass estimate). It is also assumed that the gas is in virial equilibrium or supervirialized, i.e. the velocity gradient is equal or greater than that calculated from the virial equilibrium (<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">\u2060|$K_{\\rm vir} = ({\\rm d}v/{\\rm d}r)_{\\rm LVG}/({\\rm d}v/{\\rm d}r)_{\\rm vir}\\ge 1$|\u2060</span>) as expected from normal to starburst galaxies (e.g. Papadopoulos\u00a0&amp;\u00a0Seaquist <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib61\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib61\" data-open=\"bib61\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1999</a>; Zhang et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib91\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib91\" data-open=\"bib91\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Figs\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig10\" data-open=\"fig10\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">10</a> and\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig11\" data-open=\"fig11\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">11</a> show the results graphically for the analysis of CO and [C\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">i</span>] for components <span class=\"small-caps\">i</span> and <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>, respectively, while Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a> presents the results quantitatively. In the figures, the top left-hand panel shows the observed CO SLED and the best fit (solid black line) and range of acceptable models (shaded grey regions). In the remaining plots, the central panel shows the surface likelihood distribution, with the best-fitting value appearing as an open red circle. Also, the MCMC (red) and bootstrapping (blue) results appear as error bars, where their centre indicates the 50th percentile, and the extremes the 16th and 84th percentiles. These ranges are again displayed in the top and side panels as transparent regions (vertical dotted line indicating the 50th percentile). Here, the likelihood distribution for each parameter is shown with a solid line, and its 16th, 50th, and 84th percentiles are displayed with a black error bar. In the side panels, the vertical black line indicates the best-fitting value. For completeness, the predicted [C\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">i</span>]\u2009<sup>3</sup><em>P</em><sub>1</sub>\u2212<sup>3</sup><em>P</em><sub>0</sub> velocity-integrated unmagnified flux for components <span class=\"small-caps\">i</span> and <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span> together is <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$0.72_{-0.09}^{+0.1}\\,$|</span>\u00a0Jy\u00a0km\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup>, which comprises the observed value of 0.77\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.09.</p>                        <a id=\"133989629\" scrollto-destination=\"133989629\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig10\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure\u00a010.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/486/2/10.1093_mnras_stz945/1/m_stz945fig10.jpeg?Expires=1611465158&amp;Signature=3nAqV375sYSKkox9LYf0ij~1mEcTXv74sT07vxPCIilNkPI-MmWtqmt~62aUGV4Ohnr04XNPXV09tqD3LBeHGd0nFUVuByDiTaa5dhWoD88u7wVzQV3jb57-8E9CAr0nGggim3q14VMTpL9Qp2al02WWvEl0FRl92C~g7vupvZK-nmhWOhuGE7Uw4kToZGF1NWnyHp2zq~IJkl2danmv69TU44Pk4IIn1hkhu4CpDD24pRPOkYy7DN2ahzu6tROUJrFLpbQfIJsBcFZEjm4GQm4xAhO9JsGY-GmdHHGX4U7wtjUhluo0taMS1qBfe03JaDK5PeQVkCpiyuv4tQlh0Q__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Modelling H1429\u20130028\u2019s CO and [C\u2009i] SLED with myradex for component\u2009i. Top middle and right: these panels show the likelihood distributions of the H2 mass and column density and their 15.9th, 50th, and 84.1th percentile values as error bars. The best-fitting value is marked with a dotted line, while the blue and red dotted lines and transparent regions show the 15.9th, 50th, and 84.1th percentile values for, respectively, the bootstrapping and MCMC analysis. Bottom: these three panels show the probability surface density of the molecular gas density ($n_{\\rm H_2}$), velocity gradient (v), and gas temperature (T), when comparing each with the other two. The top and side plots follow the same colour and pattern coding as the middle and right top panels.</p></div></div>                        <a id=\"133989630\" scrollto-destination=\"133989630\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig11\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure\u00a011.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/486/2/10.1093_mnras_stz945/1/m_stz945fig11.jpeg?Expires=1611465158&amp;Signature=zFPKhEYx~H59H3t0p9tsP3rNPjLtnC96WIFLSiWlb0wY3ihUrqpgvDyNHc-Vniw425Rcc2wzx9kjiNfwkhQ5Z6F2~h9HpFchSr~6IjLRCyo9PHaEsZWC4bXQgwbyaBKENWtVEx~h8nvovJr35TxftIZza8KZHLpD8kt2XiqAMfT1PO4O-CNE3YZta1DWCLNhlghv9CY7C7Ew2BLT7Fmf9aeHDeddi9GgIrkJgJsZg-GAOP2ODeLjrLFsJI6jLgNtf-ODkG2u8MOk3j4iDyM~fEHH43zYiUt5qhLBGFl2Nw6UO8Jq3WC5E7CnDLz7dRxqnqpUJYiGBmiv7TNfXIGHZA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" class=\"table-wrap-foot\"><span id=\"fn-tblf4\"></span><div content-id=\"tblf4\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>a</em></sup>The parameters in this column are: temperature, log\u2009<em>T</em>\u00a0\u2261\u00a0log(<em>T</em>\u00a0[K]); molecular gas density, log\u2009<em>n</em>\u00a0\u2261\u00a0log(<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">\u2060|$n_{\\rm H_2}$|</span>\u00a0[cm<sup>\u22123</sup>]); velocity gradient, log\u2009d<em>v</em>\u00a0\u2261\u00a0log(d<em>v</em>\u00a0[m\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup>\u00a0pc<sup>\u22121</sup>]); gas column density, log\u2009<em>N</em>\u00a0\u2261\u00a0log(<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">\u2060|$N_{\\rm H_2}$|</span>\u00a0[cm<sup>\u22122</sup>]); area filling factor, log\u2009<em>f</em>\u00a0\u2261\u00a0log(<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">\u2060|$\\langle L^{i}_{\\rm obs}/L^i_{\\rm LVG} \\rangle_{\\rm weighted}$|\u2060</span>); and molecular gas mass, log\u2009<em>M</em>\u00a0\u2261\u00a0log(<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">\u2060|$M_{\\rm H_2}$|</span>\u00a0[M<sub>\u2299</sub>]).</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-tblf5\"></span><div content-id=\"tblf5\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>b</em></sup>This column shows the log mean between the ML, MCMC, and bootstrap values.</p></span></div></div><div class=\"label\">Table\u00a02.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">CO and [C\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">i</span>] SLED analysis in H1429\u22120028.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-wrap-foot\"><span id=\"fn-tblf4\"></span><div content-id=\"tblf4\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>a</em></sup>The parameters in this column are: temperature, log\u2009<em>T</em>\u00a0\u2261\u00a0log(<em>T</em>\u00a0[K]); molecular gas density, log\u2009<em>n</em>\u00a0\u2261\u00a0log(<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">\u2060|$n_{\\rm H_2}$|</span>\u00a0[cm<sup>\u22123</sup>]); velocity gradient, log\u2009d<em>v</em>\u00a0\u2261\u00a0log(d<em>v</em>\u00a0[m\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup>\u00a0pc<sup>\u22121</sup>]); gas column density, log\u2009<em>N</em>\u00a0\u2261\u00a0log(<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">\u2060|$N_{\\rm H_2}$|</span>\u00a0[cm<sup>\u22122</sup>]); area filling factor, log\u2009<em>f</em>\u00a0\u2261\u00a0log(<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">\u2060|$\\langle L^{i}_{\\rm obs}/L^i_{\\rm LVG} \\rangle_{\\rm weighted}$|\u2060</span>); and molecular gas mass, log\u2009<em>M</em>\u00a0\u2261\u00a0log(<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">\u2060|$M_{\\rm H_2}$|</span>\u00a0[M<sub>\u2299</sub>]).</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-tblf5\"></span><div content-id=\"tblf5\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>b</em></sup>This column shows the log mean between the ML, MCMC, and bootstrap values.</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/133989631\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=133989632 id=\"133989632\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4>4 DISCUSSION</h2>\r\n                    <h3 scrollto-destination=133989633 id=\"133989633\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-1>4.1 Gas conditions</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">From Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a> and Figs\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig10\" data-open=\"fig10\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">10</a> and\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig11\" data-open=\"fig11\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">11</a>, one can see that temperature, velocity gradient, and gas density are poorly constrained and correlated. As a result, there is no significant difference within the errors in these properties between the two velocity components. The molecular gas column density and mass are better constrained, and, although both velocity components have comparable gas masses (log(<em>M</em><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$_{\\rm H_2}$|</span>\u00a0[M<sub>\u2299</sub>])\u00a0\u223c\u00a09.26), the column density is &gt;1\u03c3 higher in <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span> (log(<em>N</em><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$_{\\rm H_2}$|</span>\u00a0[cm<sup>\u22122</sup>])\u00a0=\u00a019.7<sub>\u22120.2</sub> versus 19.2<sup>+0.2</sup> in <span class=\"small-caps\">i</span>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Combined, components <span class=\"small-caps\">i</span> and <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span> have <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${M_{\\rm H_2} = 3.6_{-0.6}^{+0.5}\\times 10^9\\, \\mathrm{ M}_\\odot }$|</span> (where the errors assume the full range of uncertainty from all methods). For reference, this means that the H<sub>2</sub>-to-dynamical mass fraction (i.e. <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${M_{\\rm H_2} / M_{\\rm dyn}}$|\u2060</span>) in the NS component is <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$8_{-6}^{+3}$|</span>\u00a0per\u00a0cent.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The CO SLED seems to be intermediate between those observed on average in SMGs and quasi-stellar objects (QSOs, Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig12\" data-open=\"fig12\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">12</a>; Carilli\u00a0&amp;\u00a0Walter <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib10\" data-open=\"bib10\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>; Oteo et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib60\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib60\" data-open=\"bib60\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017b</a>). Nevertheless, compared to the CO transitions luminosity ratios presented by Carilli\u00a0&amp;\u00a0Walter (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib10\" data-open=\"bib10\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>, table\u00a02 therein), the resemblance to SMG-like ratios is strong: <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${L^{\\prime }_{32}/L^{\\prime }_{21}} = 0.7\\pm 0.2$|\u2060</span>, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${L^{\\prime }_{43}/L^{\\prime }_{21}} = 0.78\\pm 0.09$|\u2060</span>, and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${L^{\\prime }_{54}/L^{\\prime }_{21}} = 0.45\\pm 0.08$|</span> versus, respectively, average values of 0.78, 0.54, and 0.46 for SMGs or 0.98, 0.88, and 0.70 for QSOs (Carilli\u00a0&amp;\u00a0Walter <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib10\" data-open=\"bib10\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>). Given the uncertainties and the current lack of evidence supporting the presence of an accreting supermassive black hole (Timmons et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib77\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib77\" data-open=\"bib77\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>; Ma et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib48\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib48\" data-open=\"bib48\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>), H1429\u20130028 is regarded as a DSFG.</p>                        <a id=\"133989637\" scrollto-destination=\"133989637\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig12\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure\u00a012.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/486/2/10.1093_mnras_stz945/1/m_stz945fig12.jpeg?Expires=1611465158&amp;Signature=uhhQQmT5vP9kxFBRsHYlkSnne5h3bdqXuawshi31rNFcuveScAX2~r02IDNChuHW~-c8Azz6vt7Jx91iK2o4Dk3T~CCn-EI41irowqoJIaRcJI9Sb8yhCIwX6IPlYdqYWcdW55SOu9DY1CHnSB6Cvz5djj4O1XQU9YpFpNwZnEOX0PE~gztcVGZwNVjIRY~ydh489cK0ubboApw0X4JKqTMkrdS~CJqGIXC2Habemn2SoDuk-vif1nnrjPHL-iVFB5VPr53CBbDI187WpqfOzMSkfgABnr5Zb9jKydUyFANBqPgUnLHD2CCHaadLeC~iugrgpDk-jVviccPkwFwXCg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Comparing H1429\u20130028\u2019s CO SLED (the displayed values are total velocity-integrated ones) to other reported in the literature for: local IR luminous galaxies (NGC\u00a05135, NGC\u00a01068, Mrk\u00a0231; Rosenberg et\u00a0al. 2015); SMGs (Bothwell et\u00a0al. 2013); lensed SMGs (SDP\u00a081, SDP\u00a017, SMM\u00a0J2135\u20130102, HFLS3; Danielson et\u00a0al. 2011; Frayer et\u00a0al. 2011; Harris et\u00a0al. 2012; Lupu et\u00a0al. 2012; Riechers et\u00a0al. 2013; ALMA Partnership et\u00a0al. 2015). The CO\u2009(1\u20130) flux from H1429\u20130028 is that predicted from the analysis in Section\u00a03.4.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz945fig12.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/133989637/stz945fig12.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz945fig12.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"133989637\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/486/2/10.1093_mnras_stz945/1/stz945fig12.jpeg?Expires=1611465158&Signature=JxZSx8rBRHrc~wxkcqgrz3Ud4k0hr88OiTCRSffHanDrO3scoV46xWOzDtZUZvHeeB2MHxkB9wfu-HABNaNLlt5iWBbMn3yBoIW6q2kv8EA67g88kx175NBBGugxB9vYQbZ~y52LOtiVSqtU8fGvMNLqzWT4pJv25BDW9z4Xa7FpXyUF57KtJ53GDhnchDjqjH--K42ZF47ojTXsPYSwf4a8xUoHXIKO9PZxTeN6FO3BbkdacaY64PHWvQDruzt0lMvXCQp~ErunQEOqVM2iU2WJWwouHVq~0PXtqICzAGhJIz-mXsEdUn5zbbZwY3oh1AMVU0hHnHMipyQW5-PuFw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=133989637&ar=5475133&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz945fig12.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Comparing H1429\u20130028\u2019s CO SLED (the displayed values are total velocity-integrated ones) to other reported in the literature for: local IR luminous galaxies (NGC\u00a05135, NGC\u00a01068, Mrk\u00a0231; Rosenberg et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib67\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib67\" data-open=\"bib67\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>); SMGs (Bothwell et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib6\" data-open=\"bib6\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>); lensed SMGs (SDP\u00a081, SDP\u00a017, SMM\u00a0J2135\u20130102, HFLS3; Danielson et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib18\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib18\" data-open=\"bib18\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>; Frayer et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib24\" data-open=\"bib24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>; Harris et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib31\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib31\" data-open=\"bib31\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Lupu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib46\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib46\" data-open=\"bib46\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Riechers et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib66\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib66\" data-open=\"bib66\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>; ALMA Partnership et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib1\" data-open=\"bib1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>). The CO\u2009(1\u20130) flux from H1429\u20130028 is that predicted from the analysis in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3-4\"></span><a href=\"#sec3-4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3.4</a>.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig12\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure\u00a012.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/486/2/10.1093_mnras_stz945/1/m_stz945fig12.jpeg?Expires=1611465158&amp;Signature=uhhQQmT5vP9kxFBRsHYlkSnne5h3bdqXuawshi31rNFcuveScAX2~r02IDNChuHW~-c8Azz6vt7Jx91iK2o4Dk3T~CCn-EI41irowqoJIaRcJI9Sb8yhCIwX6IPlYdqYWcdW55SOu9DY1CHnSB6Cvz5djj4O1XQU9YpFpNwZnEOX0PE~gztcVGZwNVjIRY~ydh489cK0ubboApw0X4JKqTMkrdS~CJqGIXC2Habemn2SoDuk-vif1nnrjPHL-iVFB5VPr53CBbDI187WpqfOzMSkfgABnr5Zb9jKydUyFANBqPgUnLHD2CCHaadLeC~iugrgpDk-jVviccPkwFwXCg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Comparing H1429\u20130028\u2019s CO SLED (the displayed values are total velocity-integrated ones) to other reported in the literature for: local IR luminous galaxies (NGC\u00a05135, NGC\u00a01068, Mrk\u00a0231; Rosenberg et\u00a0al. 2015); SMGs (Bothwell et\u00a0al. 2013); lensed SMGs (SDP\u00a081, SDP\u00a017, SMM\u00a0J2135\u20130102, HFLS3; Danielson et\u00a0al. 2011; Frayer et\u00a0al. 2011; Harris et\u00a0al. 2012; Lupu et\u00a0al. 2012; Riechers et\u00a0al. 2013; ALMA Partnership et\u00a0al. 2015). The CO\u2009(1\u20130) flux from H1429\u20130028 is that predicted from the analysis in Section\u00a03.4.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz945fig12.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/133989637/stz945fig12.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz945fig12.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"133989637\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/486/2/10.1093_mnras_stz945/1/stz945fig12.jpeg?Expires=1611465158&Signature=JxZSx8rBRHrc~wxkcqgrz3Ud4k0hr88OiTCRSffHanDrO3scoV46xWOzDtZUZvHeeB2MHxkB9wfu-HABNaNLlt5iWBbMn3yBoIW6q2kv8EA67g88kx175NBBGugxB9vYQbZ~y52LOtiVSqtU8fGvMNLqzWT4pJv25BDW9z4Xa7FpXyUF57KtJ53GDhnchDjqjH--K42ZF47ojTXsPYSwf4a8xUoHXIKO9PZxTeN6FO3BbkdacaY64PHWvQDruzt0lMvXCQp~ErunQEOqVM2iU2WJWwouHVq~0PXtqICzAGhJIz-mXsEdUn5zbbZwY3oh1AMVU0hHnHMipyQW5-PuFw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=133989637&ar=5475133&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz945fig12.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Comparing H1429\u20130028\u2019s CO SLED (the displayed values are total velocity-integrated ones) to other reported in the literature for: local IR luminous galaxies (NGC\u00a05135, NGC\u00a01068, Mrk\u00a0231; Rosenberg et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib67\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib67\" data-open=\"bib67\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>); SMGs (Bothwell et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib6\" data-open=\"bib6\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>); lensed SMGs (SDP\u00a081, SDP\u00a017, SMM\u00a0J2135\u20130102, HFLS3; Danielson et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib18\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib18\" data-open=\"bib18\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>; Frayer et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib24\" data-open=\"bib24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>; Harris et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib31\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib31\" data-open=\"bib31\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Lupu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib46\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib46\" data-open=\"bib46\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Riechers et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib66\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib66\" data-open=\"bib66\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>; ALMA Partnership et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib1\" data-open=\"bib1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>). The CO\u2009(1\u20130) flux from H1429\u20130028 is that predicted from the analysis in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3-4\"></span><a href=\"#sec3-4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3.4</a>.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">Last, but not least, the gas conditions explaining the CO\u00a0+\u00a0[C\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">i</span>] SLED predict a CS\u2009(10\u20139) line flux \u223c200\u00a0times lower than observed. This indicates that there is either a warm component inducing the population of higher J-levels in the CO ladder, or the CS\u2009(10\u20139) emission is a result of differential magnification or chemical segregation in the background system. Follow-up observations of higher J-levels or deeper Atacama Large Millimeter/submillimeter Array (ALMA) imaging can address this issue and the incidence of the high-velocity (<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">\u2060|${\\sim }\\,$|</span>+500\u00a0km\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup>) component.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=133989639 id=\"133989639\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-2>4.2 Varying CO and carbon abundances</h3>\r\n                    <h4 scrollto-destination=133989640 id=\"133989640\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-2-1>4.2.1 Changing <em>x</em><sub>C</sub> alone</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The neutral carbon abundance adopted in the LVG analysis in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3-4\"></span><a href=\"#sec3-4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3.4</a> is <em>x</em><sub>C</sub>\u00a0=\u00a010<sup>\u22124</sup>. This value is comparable to the abundance of (8\u00a0\u00b1\u00a04)\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>\u22125</sup> that was found for a sample of submillimetre galaxies and quasar host galaxies at <em>z</em>\u00a0&gt;\u00a02 (Walter et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib86\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib86\" data-open=\"bib86\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>), and even in the centres of some local star-forming galaxies (Israel\u00a0&amp;\u00a0Baas <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib36\" data-open=\"bib36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>; Jiao et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib38\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib38\" data-open=\"bib38\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>). However, in the literature, lower values are regularly adopted or reported, down to <em>x</em><sub>C</sub>\u00a0\u223c\u00a010<sup>\u22125</sup> (Frerking et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib25\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib25\" data-open=\"bib25\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1989</a>; Sofia et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib74\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib74\" data-open=\"bib74\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>; Tomassetti et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib80\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib80\" data-open=\"bib80\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>; Israel, Rosenberg\u00a0&amp;\u00a0van der Werf <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib37\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib37\" data-open=\"bib37\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>; Jiao et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib38\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib38\" data-open=\"bib38\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">As a first assessment, one can assume local thermal equilibrium (LTE) conditions and estimate the neutral carbon mass using the [C\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">i</span>]\u2009<sup>3</sup><em>P</em><sub>1</sub>\u2212<sup>3</sup><em>P</em><sub>0</sub> line alone (see section\u00a04.4 in M14 for details on estimating <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${M_{\\rm H_2}}$|</span> based on [C\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">i</span>]). Considering a carbon excitation temperature of <em>T</em><sub>ex</sub>\u00a0=\u00a029\u00a0\u00b1\u00a06 (Walter et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib86\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib86\" data-open=\"bib86\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>) and an observed [C\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">i</span>] luminosity from components <span class=\"small-caps\">i</span> and <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span> together of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$L^{\\prime }_{\\rm [CI]10} = (2.4\\pm 0.3)\\times 10^{9}$|</span>\u00a0K\u00a0km\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup>\u00a0pc<sup>2</sup>, one retrieves <em>M</em><sub>[C\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">i</span>]</sub>\u00a0=\u00a0(3.0\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.7)\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>6</sup>\u00a0M<sub>\u2299</sub>. This implies a molecular gas mass of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${M_{\\rm H_2} = (5\\pm 1)\\times 10^9 (x_{\\rm C}/x^{\\rm alt}_{\\rm C})\\,{\\rm M}_\\odot }$|\u2060</span>, where <em>x</em><sub>C</sub>\u00a0=\u00a010<sup>\u22124</sup> and we have explicitly included the carbon abundance <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$x^{\\rm alt}_{\\rm C}$|</span> as an optional alternative to our adopted value. Within 1\u03c3, this estimated value agrees with the one obtained from the LVG analysis. One can see that the <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${M_{\\rm H_2}}$|</span> estimate will vary linearly with the <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$x_{\\rm C}/x^{\\rm alt}_{\\rm C}$|</span> ratio.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We have also redone the LVG analysis assuming <em>x</em><sub>CO</sub>\u00a0=\u00a010<sup>\u22124</sup> and <em>x</em><sub>C</sub>\u00a0=\u00a03\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>\u22125</sup>. This induces an increase in the <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${M_{\\rm H_2}}$|</span> estimate by a similar factor to which the <em>x</em><sub>C</sub> was reduced by (\u223c3), just as in the LTE assumption above. In this way, the molecular gas mass in components <span class=\"small-caps\">i</span> and <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span> would increase from <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${\\log(M_{\\rm H_2}\\,[{\\rm M}_\\odot ])} = 9.24$|</span> to 9.75 and from 9.28 to 9.77, respectively. However, although the best fit provides acceptable physical values, the peaks of the likelihood distributions and the MCMC posteriors imply very low volume densities <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$10^{2\\!-\\!3}$|</span>\u00a0cm<sup>\u22123</sup> (even unconstrained in component <span class=\"small-caps\">i</span> within the model grid), and very low velocity gradients unconstrained down to the lowest values in the model grid (<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">\u2060|$\\mathrm{ d}v = 0.1{\\rm \\,[km\\, s^{-1}\\, pc^{-1}]}$|\u2060</span>).</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=133989644 id=\"133989644\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-2-2>4.2.2 Assessing a metallicity dependence</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Finally, one can assume that both <em>x</em><sub>C</sub> and <em>x</em><sub>O</sub> are proportional to metallicity (e.g. as in Wolfire et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib89\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib89\" data-open=\"bib89\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a> or Narayanan et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib53\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib53\" data-open=\"bib53\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>), one arrives to the conclusion that <em>x</em><sub>CO</sub>\u00a0\u221d\u00a0(<em>Z</em>\u2032)<sup><em>n</em></sup>, where <em>Z</em>\u2032\u00a0=\u00a0<em>Z</em>/Z<sub>\u2299</sub>. The exponent <em>n</em> here is assumed to be dependent on <em>x</em><sub>C</sub>, <em>x</em><sub>O</sub>, and the densities of these atoms, which already points to <em>n</em>\u00a0\u223c\u00a02 if one assumes that both C and O originate from the same process (stellar activity), and no CO dissociation occurs due to less shielding effects at lower metallicity.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">As a result, we have ran the LVG analysis assuming <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$x_{\\rm C} = x^0_{\\rm C}\\times 10^{(Z-\\mathrm{ Z}_\\odot)}$|</span> and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$x_{\\rm CO} = x^0_{\\rm CO}\\times 10^{2(Z-\\mathrm{ Z}_\\odot)}$|\u2060</span>. Here, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$x^0_{\\rm C}$|</span> and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$x^0_{\\rm CO}$|</span> are the neutral carbon and CO abundances, respectively, adopted in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3-4\"></span><a href=\"#sec3-4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3.4</a>, <em>Z</em> is the measured metallicity 12\u00a0+\u00a0log(O/H)\u00a0=\u00a08.49 in H1429\u22120028 (see Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4-3-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec4-3-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">4.3.1</a>) and Z<sub>\u2299</sub> is the solar metallicity (8.69; Asplund et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib2\" data-open=\"bib2\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>). This implies <em>x</em><sub>C</sub>\u00a0=\u00a06.3\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>\u22125</sup> and <em>x</em><sub>CO</sub>\u00a0=\u00a04.0\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>\u22125</sup>. This approach results in total molecular mass of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${M_{\\rm H_2} = 5.6_{-0.9}^{+0.7}\\times 10^9\\, \\mathrm{ M}_\\odot }$|\u2060</span>, which is a factor of 1.6\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.3 higher than the estimate reported in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3-4\"></span><a href=\"#sec3-4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3.4</a>. Again, this factor is comparable to the one <em>x</em><sub>C</sub> was reduced by.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=133989647 id=\"133989647\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-2-3>4.2.3 Accounting for the abundance uncertainty</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">As made clear in the previous subsections, the <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${M_{\\rm H_2}}$|</span> estimate varies proportionally with the <em>x</em><sub>C</sub> assumption. Hence, as a conservative approach, and specifically considering the spread of the order of \u223c40\u00a0per\u00a0cent in the abundances found in the sample studied by Walter et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib86\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib86\" data-open=\"bib86\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>), a more realistic error estimate for the molecular gas estimate would be <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${M_{\\rm H_2} = 4_{-2}^{+3}\\times 10^9\\, \\mathrm{ M}_\\odot }$|\u2060</span>, where the upper error estimate also accounts for the metallicity-dependent uncertainty discussed in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4-2-2\"></span><a href=\"#sec4-2-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">4.2.2</a>. This implies an H<sub>2</sub>-to-dynamical mass fraction in the NS component of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$8_{-7}^{+6}$|</span>\u00a0per\u00a0cent.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=133989649 id=\"133989649\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-3>4.3 CO-to-H<sub>2</sub> conversion factor</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The CO/[C\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">i</span>] SLED analysis pursued in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3-4\"></span><a href=\"#sec3-4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3.4</a> (Figs\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig10\" data-open=\"fig10\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">10</a> and\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig11\" data-open=\"fig11\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">11</a>) implies a velocity-integrated J\u00a0=\u00a01\u20130 line flux of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$180_{-20}^{+20}$|</span>\u00a0mJy\u00a0km\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup>, implying a line luminosity of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$L^{\\prime }_{\\rm CO10} = 1.0_{-0.1}^{+0.1}\\times 10^{10}$|</span>\u00a0K\u00a0km\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup>\u00a0pc<sup>2</sup> (assuming a magnification of <em>\u03bc</em><sub>CO</sub>\u00a0\u223c\u00a015, Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3-3\"></span><a href=\"#sec3-3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3.3</a>). This implies that the CO-to-H<sub>2</sub> conversion factor in H1429\u22120028 is <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\alpha _{\\rm CO} = {M_{\\rm H_2}}/L^{\\prime }_{\\rm CO10} = 0.4_{-0.2}^{+0.3}$|</span>\u00a0M<sub>\u2299</sub>/(K\u00a0km\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup>\u00a0pc<sup>2</sup>), assuming <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${M_{\\rm H_2} = 4_{-2}^{+3}\\times 10^9\\, \\mathrm{ M}_\\odot }$|\u2060</span>.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=133989651 id=\"133989651\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-3-1>4.3.1 Comparison with metallicity-dependent \u03b1<sub>CO</sub> relations</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">As it has been proposed in the literature (see Bolatto, Wolfire\u00a0&amp;\u00a0Leroy <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib5\" data-open=\"bib5\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>, for a review), the CO-to-H<sub>2</sub> conversion factor (<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">\u2060|${M_{\\rm H_2+He} = \\alpha _{\\rm CO} L^{\\prime }_{\\rm CO10}}$|\u2060</span>, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${[\\alpha _{\\rm CO}] = \\mathrm{ M}_\\odot /({\\rm K\\,km\\, s^{-1}\\,pc^2})}$|\u2060</span>) appears to be dependent on gas phase metallicity, where CO gradually becomes a poor tracer of H<sub>2</sub> with decreasing metallicity.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Using 0.8\u20131.7\u00a0<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mu {\\rm m}$|</span> grism data acquired by <em>HST</em>/WFC3, Timmons et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib77\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib77\" data-open=\"bib77\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>) assessed the gas phase metallicity, 12\u00a0+\u00a0log(O/H), for H1429\u22120028. Their analysis revealed the A+B knot (fig.\u00a01 in M14) as the brightest line emitter in the Einstein ring, resembling the knot flux ratios seen at long wavelengths (<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">\u2060|$\\lambda \\gtrsim 1$|</span>\u00a0mm), and in contrast with the rest-frame optical ones. This points to the fact that line emission is dominated by the NS oriented component in the background system (fig.\u00a08 in M14) also dominating the long-wavelength spectral range.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Following the linear relation proposed by Sobral et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib73\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib73\" data-open=\"bib73\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>) between H\u03b1/[N\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] flux ratios and the logarithm of the H\u03b1\u00a0+\u00a0[N\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] equivalent width, one can use the former to estimate the metallicity based on the N2-index relations proposed by Denicol\u00f3, Terlevich\u00a0&amp;\u00a0Terlevich (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib19\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib19\" data-open=\"bib19\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>) and Pettini\u00a0&amp;\u00a0Pagel (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib63\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib63\" data-open=\"bib63\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>), giving, respectively, 12\u00a0+\u00a0log(O/H)\u00a0=\u00a08.7\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.2 and 8.6\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.2. Since the N2-index is known to saturate at metallicities close to solar, Pettini\u00a0&amp;\u00a0Pagel (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib63\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib63\" data-open=\"bib63\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>) proposed the O3N2-index that yields 8.5\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.2. Assuming a solar metallicity of 8.69 (Asplund et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib2\" data-open=\"bib2\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>), H1429\u22120028 is observed as a system with a metallicity close to solar (e.g. O3N2 estimate is 1.3\u03c3 away).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Following the metallicity\u2013[\u03b1<sub>CO</sub>] relation proposed by Genzel et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib26\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib26\" data-open=\"bib26\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>, which is based on the N2 calibration by Denicol\u00f3 et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib19\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib19\" data-open=\"bib19\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>), \u03b1<sub>CO</sub> is found to be 5.3\u00a0M<sub>\u2299</sub>/(K\u00a0km\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup>\u00a0pc<sup>2</sup>) (with an error factor of \u223c1.7).<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn6\" data-open=\"fn6\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">6</a></sup> Based on the theoretical predictions by Wolfire et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib89\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib89\" data-open=\"bib89\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>) and Glover\u00a0&amp;\u00a0Mac Low (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib29\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib29\" data-open=\"bib29\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>) (which Bolatto et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib5\" data-open=\"bib5\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>, show to best explain observations), and the empirical metallicity values just mentioned, the expected \u03b1<sub>CO</sub> is very much Milky Way-like (\u223c4.3\u20137\u00a0M<sub>\u2299</sub>/(K\u00a0km\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup>\u00a0pc<sup>2</sup>)). An alternative theoretical approach by Narayanan et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib53\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib53\" data-open=\"bib53\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>) predicts a relation between \u03b1<sub>CO</sub> and both metallicity and CO line intensity. This yields \u03b1<sub>CO</sub>\u00a0=\u00a06\u00a0\u00b1\u00a02\u00a0M<sub>\u2299</sub>/(K\u00a0km\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup>\u00a0pc<sup>2</sup>), assuming the O3N2 metallicity index value and the &lt;<em>W</em><sub>CO</sub>&gt; as measured in the source plane CO(4\u20133) moment-0 map scaled to the CO(1\u20130) flux predicted from the SLED analysis.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">However, as briefly noted in M14, such high \u03b1<sub>CO</sub> values imply <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${M_{\\rm H_2}}$|</span> values (<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">\u2060|${\\rm {\\sim} 6\\!-\\!8\\times 10^{10}\\, M_\\odot }$|\u2060</span>) comparable or higher than the estimated dynamical mass (<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">\u2060|$M_{\\rm dyn} = 5_{-2}^{+3}\\times 10^{10}$|</span>\u00a0M<sub>\u2299</sub>). As a result, these are deemed not realistic in the case of H1429\u22120028.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=133989657 id=\"133989657\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-3-2>4.3.2 Comparison with the <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$L_{\\nu _{850\\,\\mu {\\rm m}}}\\!-\\!L^{\\prime }_{\\rm CO}$|</span> relation</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Since spectral line observations are time-consuming, the statistical approach proposed by Scoville et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib69\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib69\" data-open=\"bib69\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>, see also Hughes et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib34\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib34\" data-open=\"bib34\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>; Liang et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib44\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib44\" data-open=\"bib44\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>), where the dust continuum is used as a tracer of molecular gas, has become increasingly popular, since one can study numerous galaxies in a very inexpensive way. For completeness, the application of this relation to the case of H1429\u22120028 is reported here. We note however that the relation assumes a constant galactic-like \u03b1<sub>CO</sub>\u00a0=\u00a06.5\u00a0M<sub>\u2299</sub>/(K\u00a0km\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup>\u00a0pc<sup>2</sup>)\u00a0,<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn7\" data-open=\"fn7\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">7</a></sup> hence what should actually be compared here is CO\u2009(1\u20130) luminosity. Following equation\u00a0(16) in Scoville et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib69\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib69\" data-open=\"bib69\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>, appendix\u00a0A.6), we assume a power-law index of 3.9\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.4 (M14) instead of 3.8, and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\alpha _{850} = (7\\pm 2)\\times 10^{19}$|</span>\u00a0erg/(s\u00a0Hz\u00a0M<sub>\u2299</sub>). We also consider the <span class=\"small-caps\">mbb_emcee</span><sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn8\" data-open=\"fn8\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">8</a></sup> SED fit to <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$0.1\\!-\\!1.28$|</span>\u00a0mm photometry in M14 to predict the observed flux at rest frame 850\u00a0<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mu {\\rm m}$|\u2060</span>, which avoids the need for the Rayleigh\u2013Jeans approximation correction. This implies <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${M_{\\rm H_2} = 2_{-1}^{+1}\\times 10^9 \\, \\mathrm{ M}_\\odot }$|</span> and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$L^{\\prime }_{\\rm CO10} = 4_{-2}^{+2}\\times 10^{8}$|</span>\u00a0K\u00a0km\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup>\u00a0pc<sup>2</sup>. While the <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${M_{\\rm H_2}}$|</span> mass estimate comprises the SLED analysis result, the CO(1\u20130) luminosity is a factor of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$30_{-20}^{+10}$|</span> lower than the predicted one (see values summarized in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4-3\"></span><a href=\"#sec4-3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">4.3</a>). Nevertheless, H1429\u22120028 is a lensed galaxy and the errors are still relatively large. As a result, for the time being, this predicted luminosity 1.8\u03c3 difference ought to be considered as statistically insignificant.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=133989659 id=\"133989659\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-4>4.4 The different ISM contents in the two background components</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">To the depth of the current observations, it is observed that the gas and dust emissions are totally dominated by the NS component. Since the 1.28\u00a0mm observations are probing the Rayleigh\u2013Jeans tail of the dust continuum, we can use that information as a tracer of the ISM gas in the system (Scoville et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib69\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib69\" data-open=\"bib69\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>). Here, we chose to use this property to assess the relative ISM content between the EW and NS components. From table\u00a02 in M14, it is observed that the total 1.28\u00a0mm flux is 6\u00a0\u00b1\u00a01\u00a0mJy (all assigned to the NS component), while the observations reached an rms of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$78\\, \\mu$|</span>Jy, meaning a 3\u03c3 upper limit of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$0.23$|</span>\u00a0mJy. Based on the latest lensing model, the magnification factors for the NS and EW components are 24\u00a0\u00b1\u00a01 and 11\u00a0\u00b1\u00a01, respectively.<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn9\" data-open=\"fn9\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">9</a></sup> As a result, the EW gas and dust content is &lt;9<sup>+9</sup>\u00a0per\u00a0cent <sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn10\" data-open=\"fn10\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">10</a></sup> of that observed in the NS component (i.e. <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${M_{\\rm H_2}\\, [\\mathrm{ M}_\\odot ]} &lt; 3^{+4}\\times 10^8$|\u2060</span>). A more direct comparison requires deeper 1\u00a0mm dust continuum data or higher spatial resolution observations of low-J transitions (J<sub>up</sub>\u00a0\u2264\u00a03), where a less excited CO SLED from the EW component is expected to peak, and NIR spectral observations to assess the dynamic properties of the EW component.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=133989661 id=\"133989661\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-5>4.5 Comparison with SED fitting analysis</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">In M14, we adopted a two-step approach to retrieve the background emission uncontaminated by the foreground one. We used <span class=\"small-caps\">galfit</span> in the high spatial resolution <em>F110W, H</em>, and <em>K</em><sub>s</sub> bands imaging to deblend foreground and background emission. Based on this, we later used <span class=\"small-caps\">MagPhys</span> (adopting the default low-<em>z</em> template library; da Cunha, Charlot\u00a0&amp;\u00a0Elbaz <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib15\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib15\" data-open=\"bib15\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>) to determine the foreground emission in the remainder low spatial resolution imaging. On top of this, we further corrected the background rest-frame UV/optical emission for foreground obscuration (adopting different scenarios and taking them into account in the photometry error budget) and differential magnification. Nevertheless, Ma et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib48\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib48\" data-open=\"bib48\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>) has recently shown that, even after this considered approach, depending on the star formation history assumed for the template library used for the SED fitting, one can retrieve significantly different conclusions. Also, Zhang et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib92\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib92\" data-open=\"bib92\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>) also show that the initial mass function in sources alike H1429 may be top heavy, which was not considered in M14 nor Ma et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib48\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib48\" data-open=\"bib48\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). Although these issues affect even unlensed systems, H1429 has also been shown to be comprised by two spatially separated components, one dominating the UV/optical spectral range, the other the FIR-radio one. This goes against the underlying assumption of both <span class=\"small-caps\">MagPhys</span> and <span class=\"small-caps\">cigale</span> (Noll et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib57\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib57\" data-open=\"bib57\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>) where the stellar and dust components are cospatial.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">As a result, in this paper, we avoid any discussion involving conclusions based on the SED fitting done in previous works. Since the molecular and dust content is mostly dominated by the NS component, this work is essentially a description of its properties based on the mm observations reported here and in M14.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=133989664 id=\"133989664\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5>5 CONCLUSIONS</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">In this paper, the gravitationally lensed galaxy merger HATLAS\u00a0J142935.3\u2013002836 (H1429\u20130028) at <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a01.027 presented in Messias et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib49\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib49\" data-open=\"bib49\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>) is characterized in further detail. Specifically, recent APEX observations with SHeFI-APEX2 and the recent SEPIA-Band\u00a05 instrument targeting, respectively, the CO transitions J\u00a0=\u00a06\u20135 and 3\u20132, allowed us to assess the ISM gas content in the background system.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Thanks to the recent APEX observations and previous ALMA ones, a continuous coverage of the CO-SLED from J<sub>up</sub>\u00a0=\u00a02\u20136 is now available, together with the [C\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">i</span>]\u2009<sup>3</sup><em>P</em><sub>1</sub>\u2212<sup>3</sup><em>P</em><sub>0</sub> transition. We have identified three different velocity components comprising the spectra with velocity centroids at <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$v_\\mathrm{ c}^{\\rm I} = -130_{-6}^{+6}$|</span>\u00a0km\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup>, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$v_\\mathrm{ c}^{\\rm II} = 131_{-5}^{+5}$|</span>\u00a0km\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup>, and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$v_\\mathrm{ c}^{\\rm III} = 500_{-30}^{+20}$|</span>\u00a0km\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup> (Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3-2\"></span><a href=\"#sec3-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3.2</a>). It is observed that they contribute differently to each transition, but, based on the updated lensing model, we find that the two brightest components are equally magnified by a factor of \u223c15, while the fainter one is magnified by \u223c12. We also show that the high-velocity component is morphologically much smaller than the others, which seems to agree with its expected higher degree of excitation. Only the two main components <span class=\"small-caps\">i</span> and <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span> were considered in the analysis, since the high velocity one is unconstrained in the [C\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">i</span>] spectrum; see Sections\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec3-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3.1</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3-2\"></span><a href=\"#sec3-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3.2</a>, and\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3-3\"></span><a href=\"#sec3-3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3.3</a>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Assuming a large velocity gradient scenario and a combined statistical approach (ML, MCMC, and bootstrap), the molecular gas content in H1429\u22120028 is estimated to be <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${M_{\\rm H_2} = 4_{-2}^{+3}\\times 10^9\\, \\mathrm{ M}_\\odot }$|\u2060</span>, where the error accounts for the uncertainty in neutral carbon and CO abundances. This amount of gas comprises about <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$8_{-7}^{+6}$|</span>\u00a0per\u00a0cent of the dynamical mass in the NS component. As a result, at the time of observation, this star formation event is expected to turn only up to 15\u00a0per\u00a0cent (1\u03c3 upper limit) of the total (dynamical) mass into stars. No major excitation differences between components <span class=\"small-caps\">i</span> and <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span> are observed, but the column density is apparently higher toward component <span class=\"small-caps\">i</span>. Averaging over the many statistical approaches and over the two main velocity components, the gas temperature, volume density, and velocity gradient are constrained within a factor of 3 on a galaxy-wide view. These parameters are estimated to be <em>T</em>\u00a0\u223c\u00a070\u00a0K, log\u2009(<em>n</em>[cm<sup>\u22123</sup>])\u00a0\u223c\u00a03.7, and d<em>v</em>\u00a0\u223c\u00a010\u00a0km\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup>\u00a0pc<sup>\u22121</sup>. The gas column density is constrained within a factor of 1.4 to be log\u2009(<em>N</em>[cm<sup>\u22122</sup>])\u00a0\u223c\u00a019.4; see Sections\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3-4\"></span><a href=\"#sec3-4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3.4</a> and\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4-2\"></span><a href=\"#sec4-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">4.2</a>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Compared to galaxy samples in the literature, H1429\u22120028 is observed to have a DSFG-like CO-SLED [in line with the lack of evidence thus far supporting the presence of active galactic nucleus (AGN); Timmons et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib77\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib77\" data-open=\"bib77\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>; Ma et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib48\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib48\" data-open=\"bib48\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>] and, based on the predicted CO\u00a0(1\u20130) velocity-integrated flux, a CO-to-H<sub>2</sub> conversion factor (<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">\u2060|$\\alpha _{\\rm CO} = 0.4_{-0.2}^{+0.3}$|</span>\u00a0M<sub>\u2299</sub>/(K\u00a0km\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup>\u00a0pc<sup>2</sup>)); see Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec4-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">4.1</a>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The spatially resolved dust continuum map allows us to have a first assessment of the relative ISM gas content between the two background components. We estimate that the EW component is very gas and dust poor with a content less than 9<sup>+9</sup>\u00a0per\u00a0cent of what is observed toward the NS component (i.e. <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${M^{\\rm EW}_{\\rm H_2}} &lt; 3^{+4}\\times 10^8$|</span>\u00a0M<sub>\u2299</sub>); see Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4-4\"></span><a href=\"#sec4-4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">4.4</a>.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=133989670 id=\"133989670\" class=\"backacknowledgements-title\" data-legacy-id=ack1>ACKNOWLEDGEMENTS</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The team thanks the anonymous referee for the careful reading and for the suggestions which helped clarifying the idea needed to be conveyed and the implications of the uncertainties in the analysis.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">HM thanks the opportunity given by the ALMA Partnership to work at the Joint ALMA Observatory via its fellowship programme. HM acknowledges support by FCT via the post-doctoral fellowship SFRH/BPD/97986/2013.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We thank insightful discussion with Paola Di Matteo from the GalMer team while attempting to understand this system by the use of galaxy-merger models.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We thank the comments provided by Asantha Cooray.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">NN acknowledges support from Conicyt (PIA ACT172033, Fondecyt 1171506, and BASAL AFB-170002).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Z-YZ and IO acknowledge support from the European Research Council in the form of the Advanced Investigator Programme, 321302, <span class=\"small-caps\">cosmicism</span>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">SD is supported by the UK STFC Rutherford Fellowship scheme.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">EI acknowledges partial support from FONDECYT through grant N\u00b0\u20091171710.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">DR acknowledges support from the National Science Foundation under grant number AST-1614213.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">MJM acknowledges the support of the National Science Centre, Poland through the POLONEZ grant 2015/19/P/ST9/04010; this project has received funding from the European Union\u2019s Horizon 2020 research and innovation programme under the Marie Sk\u0142odowska-Curie grant agreement no. 665778.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">This work is based on data products from observations made with APEX telescope under programmes IDs C-087.F- 0015B-2011, 087.A-0820, 088.A- 1004, and 097.A-0995.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">This paper makes use of the following ALMA data: ADS/JAO.ALMA#2011.0.00476.S. ALMA is a partnership of ESO (representing its member states), NSF (USA), and NINS (Japan), together with NRC (Canada), MOST and ASIAA (Taiwan), and KASI (Republic of Korea), in cooperation with the Republic of Chile. class=\"small-caps\">numpy</span> (Van Der Walt, Colbert\u00a0&amp;\u00a0Varoquaux <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib82\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib82\" data-open=\"bib82\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>), <span class=\"small-caps\">matplotlib</span> (Hunter <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib35\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib35\" data-open=\"bib35\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>), <span class=\"small-caps\">scipy</span> (Jones et\u00a0al. <span class=\"small-caps\">astropy</span> (a community developed core <span class=\"small-caps\">python</span> package for Astronomy, <span class=\"small-caps\">astropy</span> Collaboration et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib3\" data-open=\"bib3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>).</p>                    <h2
